  • Finance
  • US Market
  • Investment
  • Google
  • Meta
  • Microsoft
  • Tesla
  • NVIDIA
  • Amazon
  • AI

Will Documentation-Driven AI Coding Become the New 'Spaghetti Mountain'? Pros and Cons of BMAD, Spec-Kit, and OpenSpec

Oct 23, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Remember the days when ‚Äúspaghetti codeüí©‚Äù used to give everyone a headache? With AI copilots like Claude Code, Codex, and Gemini in the mix, we have stumbled into a brand-new pitfall‚Äîthe ‚Äúdocumentation spaghettiüí©.‚Äù Documentation-driven AI programming has become a hot trend: write a clear specification first, then let AI generate the code. It sounds wonderful‚Äîno more guessing what the model wants, just provide a well-written brief and code appears automatically. The truth, though, is that if you take the wrong approach, the documentation can pile up into a brand-new spaghetti mountain that leaves you laughing and crying at the same time üòÖ.

Introduction: What on Earth Are BMAD, Spec-Kit, and OpenSpec?

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction: What on Earth Are BMAD, Spec-Kit, and OpenSpec?‚Äù

Let‚Äôs start with these documentation-driven AI programming tools that are making the rounds‚Äîthey each have their own personality:

BMAD Method ‚Äì a ‚Äúbig and comprehensive‚Äù framework whose full name is Breakthrough Method for Agile AI-Driven Development. Its ambitions are huge: it tries to simulate a complete agile squad with AI. There is an analyst AI, an architect AI, a developer AI, a tester AI‚Äîeach playing a role so that planning, coding, and testing all get staged like a full production. BMAD ships with a CLI and a web UI, plus special ‚Äúscript files‚Äù and context management so the AI team can collaborate. It usually unfolds in two phases: first the ‚Äúanalyst/product manager/architect‚Äù agents do the planning and design, then the ‚ÄúScrum Master/developer‚Äù agents write the actual code. The upside is a thorough workflow that stays orderly‚Äîideal for large, complex projects that demand clear documentation and division of labor. The downside is that it is cumbersome to use, has a steep learning curve, and expects the underlying model to truly understand the documentation you write.

Spec-Kit ‚Äì an open-source utility on GitHub that layers a bit of ‚Äúprocess‚Äù on top of your existing AI coding assistant. Developers use the command line to nudge AI through a ‚ÄúSpecification ‚Üí Plan ‚Üí Tasks ‚Üí Implementation‚Äù four-step. In short, Spec-Kit asks you to nail the requirements first, then guides AI to break work down and produce code. It turns your specification markdown into an ‚Äúexecutable document‚Äù using commands like /specify, /plan, and /tasks. It is lightweight and flexible, does not force you to revamp your workflow, and is model-agnostic. Great for solo builders or small teams that want to add structure and improve AI-generated code quality.

OpenSpec ‚Äì a minimalist newcomer that believes ‚Äúsimple is better.‚Äù You write a slim Markdown spec and pair it with a handful of commands to finish the job. Its flow has only three steps: submit a change proposal, let AI produce the task list, then let AI apply the spec to modify the code. The highlight is efficiency: the specs stay lean, token usage stays low, and there is barely any metadata. It works well for individuals or small teams chasing extreme speed‚Äîminor tweaks get done in minutes. The trade-off is that model support is still limited, but it is so easy to learn that there is almost no overhead.

Spot the pattern? These tools share the same philosophy: document first, then drive the AI. The goal is to reduce the uncertainty of vibe coding by giving AI a clear rulebook so code quality becomes controllable. Ideal in theory‚Äîbut reality bites. If you are not careful, the documentation you create can morph into another giant spaghetti pile. Why does that happen? Read on.

Four Reasons Documentation Turns into a Spaghetti Mountain Even Faster

Section titled ‚ÄúFour Reasons Documentation Turns into a Spaghetti Mountain Even Faster‚Äù

1. Lack of Structure

Section titled ‚Äú1. Lack of Structure‚Äù

Code is constrained by syntax‚Äîone misplaced comma and it will not even run. Documentation is much freer, and AI is not human. When a model stares at free-form, meandering text, its comprehension goes sideways. Code is deterministic; specifications are often vague and open to interpretation. If your documentation is loosely structured, the AI sees the world through fogged glass, and it is no surprise when the code it generates veers off in the wrong direction.

2. Inconsistent AI Understanding

Section titled ‚Äú2. Inconsistent AI Understanding‚Äù

Even if you write a decent document, there is no guarantee the AI will interpret it the same way every time. Seasoned developers know the saying ‚Äúa thousand readers, a thousand Hamlets‚Äù‚Äîand AI thinks even more differently from humans. ChatGPT might implement the feature correctly today, but a different model tomorrow could distort your intent. Documentation lacks the compiler‚Äôs safety net, so misunderstandings can hide in plain sight and quietly plant landmines.

3. AI Hallucinations Amplify Errors

Section titled ‚Äú3. AI Hallucinations Amplify Errors‚Äù

We all know large language models hallucinate‚Äîconfidently fabricating details. When AI uses incomplete or ambiguous documentation to write code, the stakes rise. Miss a detail in your spec and the AI might ‚Äúfill in the gaps‚Äù with something that looks plausible but is wrong. Worse still, if that flawed AI-generated documentation or code gets reused later, another AI might treat it as gospel truth. Errors balloon like rumors: once they make it into formal docs, people and models alike will keep getting misled.

4. New Risks Introduced by the Tools Themselves

Section titled ‚Äú4. New Risks Introduced by the Tools Themselves‚Äù

Finally, consider the complexity of the tools. Adopting Spec-Kit or BMAD might require extra software and brand-new rituals. You can end up wrestling with tooling, pouring hours into crafting specs and calibrating workflows, while actual coding time shrinks. If you do not internalize the framework, you may copy templates mechanically, letting documentation drift away from the code. Like wielding a scalpel without training‚Äîthe damage can be greater than doing nothing.

How to Avoid the Pile-Up: A Tiered Playbook for Documentation Tools

Section titled ‚ÄúHow to Avoid the Pile-Up: A Tiered Playbook for Documentation Tools‚Äù

The pitfalls sound daunting, but do not lose heart. With a tiered usage strategy, documentation-driven programming can still pave a smoother road:

Use direct prompts for tiny tweaks

Section titled ‚ÄúUse direct prompts for tiny tweaks‚Äù

When you are only adjusting a small logic branch or styling tweak, there is no need to assemble a grand spec. In these cases, asking Claude Code, Codex, Gemini, GitHub Copilot, or Cursor directly is fastest. Explain the request in a sentence or two and let the AI offer a diff or snippet. You save time and stay focused. As veterans like to say: small asks do not need the full ceremony; if a quick chat solves it, skip the paperwork.

Reach for Spec-Kit or OpenSpec on medium-sized changes

Section titled ‚ÄúReach for Spec-Kit or OpenSpec on medium-sized changes‚Äù

If you are adding a mid-sized feature‚Äîmultiple steps, not massive‚Äîconsider a lightweight tool such as Spec-Kit or OpenSpec. Spend ten minutes drafting an MVP-level spec that captures key requirements and edge cases, then hand it to the AI to refine the plan and tasks. Spec-Kit decomposes work item by item; OpenSpec minimizes context switching and handles the change in a few commands. The key is to keep the spec concise, covering only what is necessary. Data shows that compact specs are easier for AI to execute faithfully and more efficient overall. Once the feature ships, remember to update canonical docs or clean up temporary specs to prevent outdated information from piling up.

Deploy BMAD for major overhauls

Section titled ‚ÄúDeploy BMAD for major overhauls‚Äù

For large-scale refactors or brand-new complex subsystems‚Äîthe real ‚Äúsurgery‚Äù‚Äîyou need a rigorous approach. This is where a multi-agent framework like BMAD earns its keep: it orchestrates end-to-end planning, architecture, and task allocation. Think of it as hiring a virtual AI team to keep big projects on the rails. Of course, humans must stay in the loop‚Äînever blindly accept each AI output; review and adjust. Before spinning up BMAD, weigh the costs: it takes time and demands strong model comprehension. That investment can pay off for long-lived initiatives, but the documentation it produces‚Äîspecs, user stories, and more‚Äîshould evolve with the code. Do not toss it aside after one run; maintain it alongside the project or you will be rebuilding from scratch next time.

No matter the scale, remember the ‚Äúdocumentation MVP‚Äù principle: the doc should cover only what is necessary and true right now. Do not chase completeness for its own sake. Many veterans delete temporary specs once a feature is done because the code itself is already clear. Instead of hoarding outdated notes that mislead people, keep a lean, accurate reference and update it as the product evolves. Documentation earns its value by reflecting reality; once it drifts, it is just dead weight.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Documentation-driven programming is a double-edged sword in the AI era. Used well, it makes development more efficient and orderly; misused, it spawns fresh spaghetti mountains. Ambitious young engineers should absolutely explore new tools, but not worship them blindly. Whether we are talking code or docs, the heart of the matter is understanding the requirement and keeping information current. Whenever you decide to write a spec or pick a tool, ask yourself: ‚ÄúIs this making the problem clearer‚Äîor just adding complexity?‚Äù

Here‚Äôs to every developer mastering these AI tools, producing docs that stay crisp and useful, and turning documentation into an asset‚Äînot a burden. We all want higher productivity, not a literal spaghetti mountain blocking the office! üí©

Tags:
  • AI
  • BMAD
  • Spec-Kit
  • OpenSpec
  • Documentation-Oriented Programming

Codex vs Claude Code: Troubleshooting iOS BLE Connection Race Conditions

Oct 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Use a real-world case to expose the pain points of iOS BLE and the divergent reasoning paths of Codex and Claude Code as AI assistants.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

When you build cross-platform BLE, iOS is always the pickier one. We were integrating with a blood glucose pump, and Android sailed through while iOS refused to respond. Even more interesting, two AI assistants‚ÄîCodex and Claude Code‚Äîreturned completely different answers. In the end, Codex hit the mark; Claude Code did not. This article reconstructs the entire process and talks about how ‚ÄúAI debugging styles‚Äù can differ.

Original Case Content (Full Text Preserved)

Section titled ‚ÄúOriginal Case Content (Full Text Preserved)‚Äù

Below is the full postmortem transcript you provided, left untouched, so it‚Äôs easy to compare and reproduce üëá

iOS BLE Connection Race Condition: Comparative Analysis of the Codex vs Claude Code Solutions

Section titled ‚ÄúiOS BLE Connection Race Condition: Comparative Analysis of the Codex vs Claude Code Solutions‚Äù

Preface

Section titled ‚ÄúPreface‚Äù

When building cross-platform Bluetooth applications, the BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy) stack on iOS often gives developers headaches. Recently our team faced a tricky iOS BLE connection problem, especially when connecting to a blood glucose pump. The interesting twist: two different AI assistants‚ÄîCodex and Claude Code‚Äîproduced entirely different solutions, and only Codex succeeded.

This article digs into the essence of the problem, contrasts the two lines of reasoning, and offers guidance for developers who run into similar issues.

Problem Background

Section titled ‚ÄúProblem Background‚Äù

Symptom Description

Section titled ‚ÄúSymptom Description‚Äù
  • Platform: iOS (CoreBluetooth framework + BabyBluetooth library)
  • Framework: Flutter cross-platform app, communicating with native iOS through Platform Channels
  • Device: Blood glucose pump (Bluetooth medical device)
  • Behavior: Android connects and communicates normally; iOS connects but cannot communicate afterward

Error Sequence

Section titled ‚ÄúError Sequence‚Äù

Comparing the Two Diagnostic Approaches

Section titled ‚ÄúComparing the Two Diagnostic Approaches‚Äù

Claude Code‚Äôs Diagnostic Steps

Section titled ‚ÄúClaude Code‚Äôs Diagnostic Steps‚Äù

Claude Code diagnosed the problem as a connection timeout, focusing on:

  1. Initial assessment: Assumed iOS connects more slowly than Android
  2. Attempted fix: Added a 20-second timeout (to match Android‚Äôs setting)
  3. Code change:
  1. Second attempt: Noticed a 2-second delay before the ‚Äúconnection success‚Äù callback
  1. Final result: Removing the delay still failed to resolve the issue

Codex‚Äôs Diagnostic Steps

Section titled ‚ÄúCodex‚Äôs Diagnostic Steps‚Äù

Codex correctly identified the true nature of the problem‚Äîa race condition:

  1. Root-cause analysis:

    • Service discovery on iOS is asynchronous
    • Flutter immediately calls setNotifyByUuid and writeByUuid after a successful connection
    • At that moment the services and characteristics may not have been discovered yet
    • That causes the operations to fail

  2. Timeline analysis:

Codex‚Äôs Solution Explained

Section titled ‚ÄúCodex‚Äôs Solution Explained‚Äù

1. Implement a Pending Operation Queue

Section titled ‚Äú1. Implement a Pending Operation Queue‚Äù

2. Cache Failed Requests inside setNotifyByUuid

Section titled ‚Äú2. Cache Failed Requests inside setNotifyByUuid‚Äù

3. Retry After Service Discovery Completes

Section titled ‚Äú3. Retry After Service Discovery Completes‚Äù

4. Queue Management for Write Operations

Section titled ‚Äú4. Queue Management for Write Operations‚Äù

Key Success Factors

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Success Factors‚Äù

1. Correct Problem Identification

Section titled ‚Äú1. Correct Problem Identification‚Äù
  • Codex: Recognized it as a race condition in asynchronous operations
  • Claude Code: Misdiagnosed it as a connection timeout

2. Understanding the Asynchronous Nature of iOS BLE

Section titled ‚Äú2. Understanding the Asynchronous Nature of iOS BLE‚Äù

CoreBluetooth workflow:

3. Importance of State Management

Section titled ‚Äú3. Importance of State Management‚Äù

Codex‚Äôs approach maintains state for pending operations, elegantly resolving asynchronous timing issues.

4. Backward Compatibility

Section titled ‚Äú4. Backward Compatibility‚Äù

Codex‚Äôs solution leaves the Flutter layer untouched by handling all complexity in native iOS code.

Lessons Learned

Section titled ‚ÄúLessons Learned‚Äù

1. Symptoms vs. Root Cause

Section titled ‚Äú1. Symptoms vs. Root Cause‚Äù
  • Don‚Äôt get misled by surface-level symptoms (like ‚Äúconnections are slow‚Äù)
  • Analyze the complete call chain
  • Understand how the underlying framework really behaves

2. Challenges of Asynchronous Programming

Section titled ‚Äú2. Challenges of Asynchronous Programming‚Äù
  • Cross-platform stacks can have very different async models
  • Operations that feel synchronous on Android may be asynchronous on iOS
  • Each platform may need its own tailored solution

3. Takeaways for AI-Assisted Development

Section titled ‚Äú3. Takeaways for AI-Assisted Development‚Äù
  • Different AIs will pitch different ways to solve the problem
  • The key is understanding the logic behind the AI‚Äôs suggestion
  • Verification and testing are still indispensable

Recommended Best Practices

Section titled ‚ÄúRecommended Best Practices‚Äù

1. iOS BLE Development Watchouts

Section titled ‚Äú1. iOS BLE Development Watchouts‚Äù

2. Build a Robust State Machine

Section titled ‚Äú2. Build a Robust State Machine‚Äù

3. Add a Retry Mechanism

Section titled ‚Äú3. Add a Retry Mechanism‚Äù

Performance Optimization Tips

Section titled ‚ÄúPerformance Optimization Tips‚Äù

1. Cache Services

Section titled ‚Äú1. Cache Services‚Äù

2. Batch Operations

Section titled ‚Äú2. Batch Operations‚Äù

3. Connection Pool Management

Section titled ‚Äú3. Connection Pool Management‚Äù

Debugging Tips

Section titled ‚ÄúDebugging Tips‚Äù

1. Add Detailed Logging

Section titled ‚Äú1. Add Detailed Logging‚Äù

2. Analyze with Instruments

Section titled ‚Äú2. Analyze with Instruments‚Äù
  • Use the Core Bluetooth template to trace BLE operations
  • Inspect timing issues
  • Detect memory leaks

3. Simulate Asynchronous Delay

Section titled ‚Äú3. Simulate Asynchronous Delay‚Äù

Summary

Section titled ‚ÄúSummary‚Äù

This case highlights how critical it is to understand the underlying framework when doing cross-platform BLE development. Codex succeeded by:

  1. Pinpointing the true root cause: a race condition, not a timeout
  2. Mastering iOS BLE‚Äôs async behavior: recognizing the asynchronous discovery flow
  3. Designing an elegant fix: pending-operation queue plus retry logic
  4. Staying backward compatible: no disruptive changes to the Flutter layer

By contrast, Claude Code‚Äôs failure reminds us:

  • Surface symptoms can be misleading
  • You must analyze the asynchronous call chain
  • Fixing symptoms alone won‚Äôt eliminate the root cause

Hopefully this write-up helps developers dealing with similar iOS BLE issues. Remember: with asynchronous code, timing issues usually matter more than timeouts.

References

Section titled ‚ÄúReferences‚Äù
  1. Apple Core Bluetooth Programming Guide
  2. BabyBluetooth iOS BLE Library
  3. Flutter Platform Channels
  4. iOS BLE Best Practices

Our Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúOur Conclusion‚Äù

Whether it‚Äôs Claude Code or Codex, the process is still ‚Äúhypothesize + verify.‚Äù Codex won this time because it guessed the race-condition root cause correctly from the start. Give Claude Code a few more runs and it could converge on the right answer too‚Äîiteration plus evidence eventually lands the fix. That‚Äôs the reality of ‚ÄúAI-led debugging‚Äù: assumptions, trial and error, and proof.

Key Takeaways Cheat Sheet (with Authoritative References)

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Takeaways Cheat Sheet (with Authoritative References)‚Äù
  • CoreBluetooth discovery and callbacks are asynchronous. Operate only after the corresponding callbacks (such as discoverServices or discoverCharacteristics:forService:) complete; precise UUID searches are more efficient.
  • ‚ÄúDiscover first, then act‚Äù is the conventional order for iOS BLE. Tutorials and field guides emphasize callback-driven, asynchronous thinking to avoid writing before discovery finishes.
  • You can discover services/characteristics via full-table or targeted UUIDs. Full scans are slower; targeted discovery is more stable.
  • BabyBluetooth wraps CoreBluetooth with block- and chain-style APIs, making it easier to flush deferred queues inside setBlockOnDiscoverCharacteristics.
  • Flutter Platform Channels bridge Dart and iOS/Android; the business-layer timing guarantees should live on the native side so Dart can‚Äôt dispatch writes prematurely.

Practical Checklist

Section titled ‚ÄúPractical Checklist‚Äù

Do these six things and iOS BLE stops tormenting you:

  • Align the sequence: lock ‚Äúconnect ‚Üí service ‚Üí characteristic ‚Üí notify ‚Üí write‚Äù into a state machine and reject writes until Ready.
  • Build a queue: enqueue write operations and notify requests, flush them in the callbacks.
  • Add idempotency: repeated setNotify/write calls must be re-entrant to prevent ‚Äúwrite storms.‚Äù
  • Add retries: exponential backoff + retry limits, backed by detailed logs.
  • Cache aggressively: cache services/characteristics and maintain connection pools to lower overhead.
  • Layer responsibilities: let Flutter ‚Äúlook successful,‚Äù but iOS must own correctness.
Tags:
  • AI
  • Rails
  • Rspec
  • Testing
  • Vibe Coding Practices

The Impact of AI on Bosses, Leaders, and Engineers

Oct 19, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

The age of artificial intelligence (AI) has arrived with a bang. From business owners to team leaders to frontline engineers, everyone‚Äôs role at work is quietly shifting. Some worry that AI will take their jobs; others are excited by the surge in efficiency. The reality is that AI is reshaping how we work at astonishing speed. How should decisions be made? How do we use the tools? How should we lead? And for introverted engineers who prefer heads‚Äëdown work in particular, is this the moment to shine‚Äîor will the social naturals race ahead? This piece looks at real cases and data to see how Bosses, Leaders, and engineers can each find new advantages in the AI tide.

Decision‚ÄëMaking and Role Redesign: What Is AI Taking Over?

Section titled ‚ÄúDecision‚ÄëMaking and Role Redesign: What Is AI Taking Over?‚Äù

AI is redrawing the workplace map. Decisions once made by people are now informed by algorithms‚Äîand in some cases automated end‚Äëto‚Äëend. Resume screening in HR, reconciliation in finance, and other routine workflows are increasingly handled by AI, freeing managers from administrative grind. Business owners (Bosses) can therefore focus more on strategic direction while delegating day‚Äëto‚Äëday operational decisions to data.

IgniteTech‚Äôs CEO Eric Vaughan took a radical step: pushing the company ‚ÄúAll in AI,‚Äù replacing as much as 80% of staff and keeping only those willing to embrace AI. He argues that ‚Äúpeople who don‚Äôt use AI will be replaced by those who do.‚Äù The results? Within three months of the transition, process‚Äëoptimization metrics improved by 300% across departments, and the finance team cut the quarterly close from five days to 48 hours. For many responsibilities, AI didn‚Äôt just add speed‚Äîit changed the game.

Leaders (team managers) are approving and monitoring less, but they now own the job of putting AI strategy into practice: training teams on new tools and re‚Äëarchitecting processes. As Andrew Ng notes, AI gives small teams the power to rival big companies: a single engineer finishing in a day what used to take six months of prototyping is no longer a myth. That reality is loosening traditional hierarchies and pushing decision rights down to the technologists on the front lines.

On the engineering side, parts of basic coding and testing are auto‚Äëgenerated, pulling engineers up into higher‚Äëlevel design and optimization. Newcomers, with AI support, can deliver products in a language they don‚Äôt yet know within days. AI is redefining role boundaries: it frees people from repetition, but it also requires continuous upskilling and new responsibilities in human‚ÄëAI collaboration.

Tooling and Efficiency Leaps: How Is AI Changing the Pace of Work?

Section titled ‚ÄúTooling and Efficiency Leaps: How Is AI Changing the Pace of Work?‚Äù

In the AI wave, new tools are proliferating and accelerating the pace of work. For developers, GitHub Copilot and similar code assistants feel like pair‚Äëprogramming with a tireless partner; official data shows it has increased development speed by 55%. And it‚Äôs not just programmers‚Äînearly every role now has an AI helper: marketers brainstorm with ChatGPT, designers use Midjourney to generate concept art, and product managers lean on smart analytics to interpret user data.

According to a joint Microsoft and LinkedIn study, 75% of employees already use generative AI at work, and 68% say their workload and tempo are more demanding than before‚Äîyet AI is helping them cope. Many even bring their own AI tools to work (especially in SMBs). This ‚ÄúAI‚Äëpartner‚Äù model dramatically boosts personal throughput‚Äîtasks that used to require a team can now be done by one person plus AI.

Leaders can therefore reallocate people from mechanical, repetitive work to creative, higher‚Äëvalue problems. Microsoft‚Äôs Copilot for Office, for instance, can automatically capture meeting takeaways and generate action items, smoothing team collaboration.

Business owners are actively arming their teams, too: companies like IgniteTech reimburse every employee for ChatGPT Plus and set up dedicated ‚ÄúAI Days‚Äù for intensive practice. Forward‚Äëlooking Bosses have found that employees who embrace AI typically produce more‚Äîand they reward that with bonuses and promotions. Surveys show that more than two‚Äëthirds of leaders say they won‚Äôt hire candidates who know nothing about AI; even less experienced candidates who are fluent with AI are preferred.

Engineers are also experiencing ‚ÄúAI hyper‚Äëgrowth‚Äù: some use AI to rapidly fill skill gaps; juniors, with Copilot, produce mid‚Äëlevel code; seniors become the fabled ‚Äú10x engineers.‚Äù The flip side of tooling is fiercer competition‚Äîthose who don‚Äôt learn AI are getting left behind. For those willing to learn, however, AI is becoming a force‚Äëmultiplier for productivity.

Leadership Style Shift: From Controller to Enabler

Section titled ‚ÄúLeadership Style Shift: From Controller to Enabler‚Äù

With AI and greater information transparency, leaders must evolve their role. The classic manager once acted like a commander‚Äîcontrolling the field and making every call. Today, AI makes analysis and options far more accessible, and frontline employees can propose data‚Äëdriven recommendations. In this environment, Leaders who cling to ‚ÄúI decide everything‚Äù risk slowing innovation.

As Andrew Ng has said, when ‚Äú10x talent‚Äù emerges on a team, ‚Äúthe best person to make a decision is sometimes the engineer, not the manager.‚Äù Traditional pyramids push information up and ask leaders to decide. In the AI era, specialists armed with intelligent tools hold rich context and alternatives‚Äîand should receive greater decision autonomy.

Successful leaders are starting to play the roles of ‚Äúgardener‚Äù and coach: creating fertile ground for trial‚Äëand‚Äëerror and innovation rather than doing everything themselves. Modern organizations must distribute decision rights throughout the structure so experts at the edge can respond quickly. That requires Leaders to trust their teams, let go more, and bring technically savvy frontline colleagues into important decisions.

The same applies to the Boss level: many business owners now establish a Chief AI Officer (CAIO) role, weaving AI strategy into executive decision‚Äëmaking and asking functions to report regularly to the AI team.

Beyond delegation, leadership is getting ‚Äúsofter.‚Äù Because AI can offer objective options, leaders increasingly need empathy and judgment to balance technology with humanity. One clear trend: managers are investing more in team learning. Surveys show that as many as 62% of employees feel they lack the skills to use AI effectively and safely, while only about one in ten believe they have what they need. In response, leaders are providing AI training resources to close the skills gap‚Äîfor example, some companies host a monthly ‚ÄúAI Sharing Day,‚Äù with leaders participating alongside employees.

In short, AI‚Äëera leadership is shifting from command‚Äëand‚Äëcontrol to empowerment‚Äëand‚Äëcollaboration. Not everyone who uses AI is a ‚Äújunior‚Äù; the leaders who can activate these ‚ÄúAI power users‚Äù will be the ones who pull their teams ahead.

Opportunities for Introverted Engineers: How Does AI Amplify Quiet Strength?

Section titled ‚ÄúOpportunities for Introverted Engineers: How Does AI Amplify Quiet Strength?‚Äù

AI affects engineers differently, but for many who are introverted and technically strong, this may be the best moment to shine. In the past, outspoken teammates could attract attention by presenting well, while introverts‚Äîeven highly capable ones‚Äîmight remain unnoticed. Today, AI tools can act as an amplifier for expression and a superb partner for execution.

There‚Äôs a growing view that AI offers introverts new ways to collaborate and express ideas‚Äîletting thinking cut through social friction and reach the heart of the problem. Introverted engineers no longer need to worry as much about ‚Äúperforming‚Äù in front of others; they can focus on deep thought and high‚Äëquality output. Their ability for independent inquiry is being amplified as never before.

Real‚Äëworld stories back this up. In one software team, several quiet members flourished after adopting AI. They used models to better understand customer feedback, then engaged clients with greater confidence‚Äîultimately improving results significantly. Picture an engineer skilled at independent problem‚Äësolving, paired with an AI copilot; together they may produce what used to take a ten‚Äëperson team. These quiet ‚Äúdeep divers,‚Äù once aided by AI, can deliver startling results.

Notably, the AI era is making ‚Äú10x engineers‚Äù more common‚Äîthey may say little, but by mastering the tools, they work several times faster than most. Companies are willing to pay for such talent; top engineers may earn three times an average engineer‚Äôs compensation.

That said, introverted engineers must beware the comfort‚Äëzone trap. Over‚Äëreliance on AI as a substitute for communication can weaken social skills. On one hand, AI makes it easier for introverts to stand out on the strength of their work. On the other, excellent engineers don‚Äôt avoid communication‚Äîthey use AI to boost their technical articulation and still invest in the human collaboration that AI can‚Äôt replace. Play to your strengths while shoring up gaps, and the ‚Äúquiet‚Äù technologist can become a surprising disruptor in the AI age.

Role Changes at a Glance

Section titled ‚ÄúRole Changes at a Glance‚Äù

Below is a table summarizing how Bosses, Leaders, and engineers are changing in the AI era, and how to respond:

Dimension of ChangeBoss (Business Owner)Leader (Team Manager)Engineer (incl. introverts)
Decision‚Äëmaking & workflowMore data‚Äëdriven decisions; heavy automation of daily processes; flatter structures with more frontline authority.Fewer transactional approvals; focus on strategic guidance; emphasize cross‚Äëfunctional collaboration; reshape processes for AI.AI handles repetitive tasks; engineers focus on high‚Äëvalue work; more chances to deliver end‚Äëto‚Äëend independently.
AI tool adoptionDrive AI enablement company‚Äëwide; invest in AI infra and training; learn AI personally to set direction.Lead by example; spread AI tools to raise team efficiency; use AI to watch metrics and assist management.Everyone has an AI assistant (coding, writing, etc.); productivity surges; keep learning new tools and become an ‚ÄúAI power user.‚Äù
Management/collaboration styleShift from command to empowerment; encourage bottom‚Äëup innovation; foster an open learning culture.Delegate to experts; act as mentor and coordinator; emphasize empathy and communication to rally the team.More autonomy and remote collaboration; use AI to aid expression (smart docs, chatbots) and improve team efficiency.
Skills and traits neededUnderstand AI strategy and ethics; decide fast to capture AI opportunities; embrace change and continual learning.Working AI literacy to guide the team; data‚Äëdriven judgment; higher EQ; change‚Äëmanagement capability.Deep domain skills + AI fluency; introverts add communication skills; combine independence with teamwork.
Advantages and opportunitiesUse AI to cut cost and raise output; small teams achieve big results; agile transformation wins market timing.Free management bandwidth to focus on strategy and innovation; build a resilient, ‚ÄúAI‚Äënative‚Äù team.Talent value polarizes; those who master AI rise faster in pay and role; introverts stand out as scarce 10x talent.

Conclusion: Ride the Wave and Find Your Edge

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion: Ride the Wave and Find Your Edge‚Äù

In the AI era, no one is untouched‚Äîbut no one is fated to be left behind. The key is to move with the current. Bosses need foresight: embrace AI so the company runs faster, while keeping a human touch so technology doesn‚Äôt devolve into cold KPIs. Leaders must shift posture‚Äîfrom order‚Äëgiver to team coach‚Äîhelping everyone grow, arming the team with AI while rallying people with sincerity. Engineers should stay curious and keep learning, treating AI as a trusted copilot while pushing the ceiling of their own skills.

Introvert or extrovert, everyone can find a point of leverage in the AI wave‚Äîperhaps a distinctive specialty you can own end‚Äëto‚Äëend, or a cross‚Äëdisciplinary idea that breaks new ground. Used well, AI is a double‚Äëedged sword: offload the mechanical to machines and bring your creativity and warmth to the forefront.

In this age of change, roles can be redefined, but effort and insight remain the surest path to advantage. May we each find our edge in the AI era, ride the wind, and evolve together.

Tags:
  • AI

Bank Turmoil, Liquidity, and Tariffs: A Small‚ÄëTown Depositor‚Äôs Market Adventure

Oct 18, 2025
Vibe Sparking

This is a story about where money comes from and where it goes. The protagonist isn‚Äôt Wall Street‚Äîit‚Äôs us: salaries coming in, buying funds, skimming headlines‚Ä¶ When two US regional banks run into trouble, the Fed hints at a ‚Äústop to balance‚Äësheet runoff,‚Äù the 10‚Äëyear Treasury yield dips below 4%, and rumors swirl about a potential US‚ÄìChina meeting‚Äîhow do these seemingly far‚Äëoff events end up walking straight into our accounts?

Chapter 1 | The Teller‚Äôs ‚ÄúBad News‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúChapter 1 | The Teller‚Äôs ‚ÄúBad News‚Äù‚Äù

Early Friday, before the small‚Äëtown branch fills up, an alert flashes on the lobby display:

‚ÄúZions Bank disclosed a $50 million loan loss; Western Alliance said it filed a lawsuit in August against a borrower called Cantor Group V, suspecting collateral fraud.‚Äù

The branch manager whispers: ‚ÄúNot a systemic blow‚Äëup‚Äîlikely idiosyncratic fraud‚Äîbut the stocks will sell off first and ask questions later.‚Äù The fixed‚Äëincome manager chimes in: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt underestimate this; ‚Äòsurprises‚Äô like these make people more afraid of risk‚Äîso they rush for safer debt.‚Äù Sure enough, the 10‚Äëyear Treasury yield intraday dipped toward ~3.93%‚Äì4%‚Äîprices up, yields down.

Aside: This isn‚Äôt ‚Äúall banks are in trouble.‚Äù It‚Äôs that isolated cases tighten market nerves. When nerves tighten, money hides in bonds‚Äîand stocks are more prone to a quick ‚Äújump scare.‚Äù

Chapter 2 | The Edge of the Pool

Section titled ‚ÄúChapter 2 | The Edge of the Pool‚Äù

Think of the financial system as a giant pool:

  • Fed balance‚Äësheet runoff (QT) = water draining slowly.
  • Treasury General Account (TGA) = the government‚Äôs storage tank; when it‚Äôs very full, the banking system temporarily gets less water.
  • Overnight Reverse Repo (ON RRP) = a ‚Äúbackup bucket‚Äù in the corner; once it‚Äôs empty, you rely more on the main pool.

On Tuesday, Chair Powell said:

‚ÄúWe may be approaching, over the next few months, a point to stop the runoff. We‚Äôre seeing signs‚Äîlike repo rates‚Äîthat liquidity is getting tighter.‚Äù

Meanwhile, the market is glued to the waterline of bank reserves‚Äîthe main pool. As it drifts near ~$3 trillion, people ask: Can we keep draining without hitting the bottom? (See the weekly H.4.1.) The ON RRP ‚Äúbackup bucket‚Äù has almost been drained this year, meaning further ‚Äúpulls‚Äù more directly touch bank reserves. On the fiscal side, the TGA sits around ~$850 billion in mid‚ÄëOctober‚Äîstill quite full.

Aside: Low waterline + backup bucket near empty + a full storage tank makes people hug the ‚Äúsafe edge‚Äù (buy Treasuries). Equities get more selective.

Chapter 3 | Good Companies Still Get Rained On

Section titled ‚ÄúChapter 3 | Good Companies Still Get Rained On‚Äù

Ironically, fundamentals aren‚Äôt bad.

  • ASML: Q3 net sales ‚Ç¨7.5B, gross margin 51.6%; guided for a strong Q4 and even said 2026 won‚Äôt be below 2025.
  • TSMC: Q3 revenue $33.1B, gross margin 59.5%; Q4 outlook $32.2‚Äì$33.4B.

Aside: The rain isn‚Äôt falling from fundamentals; it‚Äôs coming from liquidity and sentiment. Companies with big umbrellas (strong cash flow, healthy balance sheets) dry off quickly.

Chapter 4 | Winds from Overseas: Rare Earths and Tariffs

Section titled ‚ÄúChapter 4 | Winds from Overseas: Rare Earths and Tariffs‚Äù

More gusts arrive from the sea:

  • China expanded rare‚Äëearth export controls on Oct 9 (added elements/tech), tightening global supply nerves.
  • In the US, talk of 100% tariffs ebbs and flows‚Äîheadlines alternately harden and soften‚Äîwhile ‚Äúwill they meet around APEC‚Äù becomes a running cliffhanger.

Aside: These are exogenous shocks. Even if a company doesn‚Äôt change, its valuation may.

Chapter 5 | A ‚ÄúRainy‚ÄëDay Trio‚Äù for New Investors

Section titled ‚ÄúChapter 5 | A ‚ÄúRainy‚ÄëDay Trio‚Äù for New Investors‚Äù

  1. First, watch the waterline (don‚Äôt be stubborn):

    • Clearer signals of stopping QT + repo rates easing = lighter rain.
    • With ON RRP near empty, if reserve balances stop falling and stabilize, that‚Äôs an early ‚Äúclearing‚Äù sign.
    • If the 10‚Äëyear yield holds around ~4% (or breaks lower and doesn‚Äôt snap back), risk appetite can recover.

  2. Next, pick your umbrella (don‚Äôt over‚Äëoptimize):

    • Leaders with steady cash flow and healthy balance sheets (e.g., upstream semi equipment/foundry) better withstand showers.
    • When bank idiosyncrasies pop up, keep sector exposure lighter and more diversified until disclosures are clearer.

  3. Finally, mind the sea breeze (don‚Äôt tune it out):

    • The path of rare earths and tariffs drives manufacturing costs and valuations; around key meetings, read twice before acting.

Chapter 6 | One‚ÄëPage Memo

Section titled ‚ÄúChapter 6 | One‚ÄëPage Memo‚Äù
  • Spark for this bout: idiosyncratic regional‚Äëbank credit issues ‚Üí risk‚Äëoff ‚Üí bonds up/yields down ‚Üí equities pressured.
  • Deeper water forces: hints that QT is nearing its end + reserve ‚Äúlower bound‚Äù + RRP near empty + elevated TGA.
  • Fundamental contrast: leaders still strong (ASML, TSMC).
  • Biggest external swing factor: rare‚Äëearth and tariff headlines tug at valuations.

One‚Äësentence strategy: Treat this as a ‚Äúliquidity shower,‚Äù not a ‚Äúhouse collapse.‚Äù Go lighter and stagger entries while it pours; run faster when it clears. Three weather gauges: (1) stop‚ÄëQT signals (2) reserves and RRP (3) the 10‚Äëyear yield.

Bonus | ‚ÄúWhy do headlines obsess over yields?‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúBonus | ‚ÄúWhy do headlines obsess over yields?‚Äù‚Äù

Because yields are like the market‚Äôs thermometer:

  • When they fall (to ~4%), it shows people are grabbing Treasuries to hide from the rain.
  • When they stabilize or rise, it often means the rain has stopped‚Äîand there‚Äôs more sunshine for stocks.
Tags:
  • Finance
  • US Market
  • Investment
  • JPMorgan
  • Goldman Sachs
  • Citi
  • Wells Fargo
  • BlackRock
  • S&P 500
  • Nasdaq
  • AI

Writing Code Is Surface‚ÄîThinking Is the Essence of Software Development

Oct 18, 2025
Vibe Sparking

‚ÄúCode is just a tool; thinking is the core.‚Äù

If you‚Äôre a product manager, indie maker, or junior developer, that line may feel counterintuitive. Yet in day‚Äëto‚Äëday engineering, we repeatedly discover: programming is 90% thinking and 10% typing. With Claude Code, ChatGPT, and Google Gemini making code generation easier than ever, this truth is now crystal clear. If AI can write code for us‚Äîwhere does our value really lie?

Consider a few common scenes: to deliver a seemingly simple feature, a developer spends ages on design‚Äîthen needs only half a day to write the code. Or a production bug takes two days to investigate from logs to root cause‚Äîbut the fix is a single line. PMs often wonder: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just a small feature‚Äîwhy so long to write some code?‚Äù The reality: coding has never been the hardest part. The hard part is ‚Äúwhat exactly are we building, and how?‚Äù Software development is fundamentally about thinking, not mechanical typing.

In an AI‚Äëaccelerated era, this stands out even more. Over 81% of developers now use AI coding assistants. One bank‚Äôs tech team reported a 40% reduction in coding time and a defect‚Äëdetection accuracy up to 92% after adopting an assistant‚Äîyet the lead still emphasized: ‚ÄúAI‚Äëgenerated code requires human review‚Äîespecially around security logic and business rules. Developers must remain in charge.‚Äù In the end, concurrency control written by AI was revised by humans due to potential risks. The essence of human‚ÄëAI collaboration is clear: AI handles repetitive, standardized work; humans handle creative, complex decisions. In other words, AI can be your ‚Äúhelper‚Äù that outputs code‚Äîbut what ultimately determines software success is still the thinking and judgment in your head.

Below, we‚Äôll walk through real everyday scenarios to see how ‚Äúthinking‚Äù dominates‚Äîand how AI coding assistants take over the busywork so you can focus on what matters most.

Scenario 1: Implementing business features ‚Äî think first, then code

Section titled ‚ÄúScenario 1: Implementing business features ‚Äî think first, then code‚Äù

When a new requirement lands, newcomers often rush to code. Experienced engineers suppress that impulse and first invest heavily in understanding the business: what problem does the requirement solve? What rules and edge cases exist? How should data flow? Only after clarifying the logic can we write correct code. Coding is translating a mental design into a language a computer executes. The translation isn‚Äôt the hard part‚Äîhaving the design is.

Take a familiar task: implement ‚Äúorder placement deducts inventory‚Äù in e‚Äëcommerce. The time sink is clarifying the rules behind ‚Äúdeduct inventory‚Äù‚Äîwhat happens if stock is insufficient? How do we prevent overselling under concurrency? How do we roll back on failure? Each question demands careful thought and design. By comparison, the final call to the inventory service to decrement a number may be only a few lines. If the logic isn‚Äôt thought through, more code won‚Äôt save you; if it is, the code is often just a handful of lines.

With AI tools, ‚Äúthink before you code‚Äù becomes more efficient. Once you‚Äôve designed the logic, ask ChatGPT or Claude to produce a first pass of the implementation‚Äîsaving time and effort. But note: AI won‚Äôt think through requirements for you. It doesn‚Äôt grasp the business essence; it only generates code from your description. You must be the ‚Äúbrain,‚Äù conveying intent precisely. In a way, AI forces us to be more rigorous: instructions must be clear, or the output will drift. Once again: before writing business code, think through the business logic. Code quality rises and falls with the depth of your thinking.

Scenario 2: Integrating third‚Äëparty APIs ‚Äî understanding beats typing

Section titled ‚ÄúScenario 2: Integrating third‚Äëparty APIs ‚Äî understanding beats typing‚Äù

Many of us have integrated a third‚Äëparty API. At first glance, it seems like ‚Äújust a few HTTP calls‚Äù‚Äîbut where‚Äôs the real time sink? Reading and understanding the documentation: which URL does what, what parameters are required, how to auth/sign, response formats, what error cases to handle. Mapping the flow and edge cases can consume hours before a single line of code is written.

For example, integrating a payment platform: you have to find the correct endpoint, understand the order schema, learn the retry strategy and error codes, then design your system‚Äôs call sequence and resilience. Once that‚Äôs clear, the coding is mostly assembling HTTP requests and parsing responses. With AI helpers, this gets easier; you can paste relevant docs or schemas and have AI draft the client code.

But API integration fundamentally tests learning and comprehension. We play the role of ‚Äútranslator,‚Äù turning a foreign system into local code. AI accelerates translation, but it can‚Äôt replace grasping the ‚Äúoriginal meaning.‚Äù Without context, AI might miss key parameters or misuse flows‚Äîleaving traps for humans to catch later. So invest time in understanding the API‚Äôs business meaning and planning the call strategy, not just in the mechanics of writing the code. With that mindset‚Äîand AI to produce the scaffolding‚Äîyou‚Äôll get twice the results for half the effort.

Scenario 3: Fixing bugs ‚Äî analysis costs more than the edit

Section titled ‚ÄúScenario 3: Fixing bugs ‚Äî analysis costs more than the edit‚Äù

Debugging is everyday life. As the joke goes: ‚Äú30 minutes to write, 3 hours to debug.‚Äù When a bug appears, the first step isn‚Äôt editing code‚Äîit‚Äôs investigation: reproduce, inspect logs, read surrounding code, hypothesize likely causes, and narrow the search. It‚Äôs a mystery to solve‚Äîlogic, inference, and understanding the system deeply. Once you find the root, the change is often trivial.

Imagine maintaining a complex system when sporadic errors are reported. You pore over logs to triangulate the module; add debug prints and replay runs to isolate conditions; even sketch a flowchart to unravel the execution path. After this mental work, you discover a missing null check in a rare branch. Adding that guard takes five minutes‚Äîthe time went into thinking and locating, not typing.

Where can AI help? Today, AI is a capable assistant, not a substitute. You can feed failing code and logs to ChatGPT to brainstorm likely causes‚Äîit often produces useful leads. But deciding the truth and validating hypotheses still falls to you. Real debugging involves the project‚Äôs context, architecture, and business logic; it‚Äôs rarely ‚Äúone faulty line.‚Äù Without the full picture, AI suggestions can be off‚Äëtarget. Humans carry the global model of the system, weigh signals, and decide.

Some tools are improving here. Anthropic‚Äôs Claude is strong at step‚Äëby‚Äëstep reasoning, listing thorough investigation steps; OpenAI‚Äôs ChatGPT is quick with obvious fixes. Treat them like a conversational mirror and advisor‚Äîexplaining symptoms to clarify your own thinking and catch missed details. Even if AI proposes a patch, validate it carefully. Debugging remains a human‚Äëled exploration and inference process; AI accelerates insight.

Scenario 4: Writing tests ‚Äî designing cases matters more than code

Section titled ‚ÄúScenario 4: Writing tests ‚Äî designing cases matters more than code‚Äù

‚ÄúNo tests, no quality.‚Äù Writing tests is another case where design outweighs typing: the hardest part is imagining scenarios and cases‚Äîwhat to test, what can go wrong. Converting that into test code is relatively mechanical.

As one senior SDET put it: designing tests is sparring with your own code. You must dream up edge cases, boundary conditions, and invalid inputs to challenge robustness. For an order system, you might design: ‚ÄúWhat happens when demand exceeds stock?‚Äù, ‚ÄúHow should order flow behave under DB connection drops?‚Äù, ‚ÄúIs the result consistent under 1,000 concurrent orders?‚Äù Each scenario demands deep understanding plus a critical mindset. That mental investment is most of the work; writing the asserts and fixtures is just staging the play.

The good news: AI shines at generating test code. You can feed a function and ask for targeted unit tests. It will often produce solid coverage and even infer developer intent from comments and context. But human judgment still decides whether tests are necessary, sufficient, and reasonable. As one developer quipped: ‚ÄúAI is great at turning ‚Äòwrite a test to verify‚Ä¶‚Äô into runnable code. Your job is to invent inputs that could break the code‚Äîwithout slogging through the boilerplate.‚Äù

Scenario 5: Designing technical solutions ‚Äî architects live in the thinking layer

Section titled ‚ÄúScenario 5: Designing technical solutions ‚Äî architects live in the thinking layer‚Äù

When planning a new system or technical approach, engineers switch to pure thinking mode: a new recommendation algorithm, a microservices layout, or a sharding plan. Little to no production code is written at first. We apply experience, knowledge, and creativity to sketch the blueprint on a whiteboard or in a doc.

We consider: business and non‚Äëfunctional requirements (performance, scalability, security, etc.); possible options and their trade‚Äëoffs and complexity; and which path is most robust. This is mental work. We draw architecture diagrams, enumerate modules, and write design docs‚Äîvisualized thinking that clarifies the path. Once the plan is set, implementation comes later.

AI can assist here too: have ChatGPT show pattern examples, industry best practices, or produce an outline for you to refine. But the architect‚Äîgrounded in business context‚Äîmakes the final call. If anything, AI‚Äôs rise highlights how architecture depends on human insight. General advice from corpora can‚Äôt know your team‚Äôs constraints or long‚Äëterm goals; only you can weigh them.

We‚Äôre also seeing early signs of ‚Äúrepository‚Äëlevel‚Äù assistants that generate whole codebases from high‚Äëlevel prompts. Tempting as ‚Äúone‚Äëclick projects‚Äù sound, they‚Äôre not production‚Äëready today; outputs are often brittle. Even as they improve, they‚Äôll still need architects to think through the design and feed it in. Research suggests these tools are most useful for freeing developers to focus on higher‚Äëlevel design and deployment decisions‚ÄîAI does the low‚Äëlevel details, humans steer.

In short, when designing solutions, we are thinkers and decision‚Äëmakers‚Äînot just code craftsmen. A good design beats a poor implementation; a clear, reasonable design slashes build and maintenance costs. If you skip the thinking and rush into code, the hidden traps cost 10‚Äì100x later. AI doesn‚Äôt change this; it reinforces it: code can be delegated, but creative responsibility cannot.

Conclusion: Be a better thinker in the AI era

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion: Be a better thinker in the AI era‚Äù

Whether you‚Äôre a PM, indie maker, or new developer, hopefully these scenarios resonate: the core advantage in software isn‚Äôt typing code‚Äîit‚Äôs thinking deeply and solving problems. As the saying goes, ‚ÄúProgramming is 90% thinking and 10% typing.‚Äù AI makes this truer than ever. With code generation offloaded, our value lies in asking the right questions, making sound decisions, and solving complex problems creatively‚Äîskills AI cannot yet replace.

For product managers, recognizing the ‚Äúthinking load‚Äù in development helps set better timelines and expectations. When a dev estimates a week, don‚Äôt fixate on lines of code; appreciate the design tradeoffs and mental work. Try having AI produce a quick prototype; you‚Äôll feel firsthand that moving from 0‚Üí1 is really about turning fuzzy goals into a clear plan. When the early thinking is done well, implementation flows.

For indie or full‚Äëstack engineers, you wear many hats and must balance thinking vs. coding. With AI, offload repetitive work‚Äîscaffolds, CRUD, format conversions‚Äîand conserve your brainpower for choices only you can make: product ideas, architecture selection, and core algorithm design. Many of us are already shifting from ‚Äúwriting code‚Äù to ‚Äúdesigning, decomposing, prompting, and reviewing.‚Äù The sooner you adapt, the more competitive you‚Äôll be.

For juniors, don‚Äôt fear AI‚Äîor resign yourself to being its typist. Treat AI as mentor and tool. Ask ‚Äúwhy,‚Äù and use it to learn higher‚Äëlevel knowledge. Surveys show many developers‚Äô top AI use case is learning‚Äînew tech, best practices, and more. First, analyze and design on your own; then ask AI for alternative implementations and compare. Learn fast by closing the gap. Avoid tossing problems to AI without understanding‚Äîotherwise you risk hollowing out your skills. AI ultimately serves thinkers. Those who don‚Äôt think will fall behind‚Äîthis only becomes more true in the AI era.

Finally, AI coding assistants don‚Äôt let our brains go off duty. Quite the opposite: they push us to understand where our value lies. If typing is automatable, we should invest time in understanding the business deeply, designing carefully, enforcing quality, and innovating continuously. That won‚Äôt make us obsolete‚Äîit will make us more effective and creative.

Let AI be the ‚Äúcode laborer.‚Äù Let us be better ‚Äúsystem designers‚Äù and ‚Äúproblem‚Äësolving experts.‚Äù As we learn to delegate implementation to AI, we‚Äôll find ideas ship faster, and once‚Äëdaunting tasks become manageable because we have more time to think. The essence of software remains thinking‚Äîunchanged, only now with clearer division of labor: machines write obediently; humans think wisely.

May this piece encourage you to bet on thinking‚Äîand to embrace AI as leverage. Offload the repetitive; let your mind create more value. üéâ

Tags:
  • AI

Q3 2025 AI Chip Supply Chain Earnings Start Strong: ASML and TSMC Beat ‚Äî Where Does NVIDIA Go from Here?

Oct 16, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Opening: Tech Earnings Season Kicks Off, Supply‚ÄëChain Confidence Surges

Section titled ‚ÄúOpening: Tech Earnings Season Kicks Off, Supply‚ÄëChain Confidence Surges‚Äù

As this earnings season shows, the AI chip supply chain is firing on all cylinders. ASML and TSMC both delivered upside surprises in their Q3 2025 results. More importantly, both turned distinctly more optimistic in their outlooks ‚Äî a sharp contrast with their cautious tone three months ago.

ASML Q3 Highlights

Section titled ‚ÄúASML Q3 Highlights‚Äù
  • Revenue ‚Ç¨7.5B (‚âà$8.2B), gross margin 51.6%
  • Net income ‚Ç¨2.125B, above market expectations
  • Q4 guidance raised sharply to ‚Ç¨9.2‚Äì9.8B; gross margin 51%‚Äì53%
  • The key shift: management explicitly said 2026 revenue will not be below 2025, reversing prior uncertainty

TSMC‚Äôs Record Q3

Section titled ‚ÄúTSMC‚Äôs Record Q3‚Äù
  • Revenue NT$989.92B (‚âà$32.2B), up 39% y/y
  • Net income NT$452.3B (‚âà$14.8B), a record high
  • ADR EPS up 39% y/y; dynamic P/E only 33x, PEG < 1
  • Full‚Äëyear revenue growth target raised from 30% to 35%
  • Gross margin at a strong 59.5%, underscoring pricing power

The core message from both prints: AI acceleration is itself being accelerated.

Supply‚ÄëChain Triangle: ASML ‚Üí TSMC ‚Üí NVIDIA

Section titled ‚ÄúSupply‚ÄëChain Triangle: ASML ‚Üí TSMC ‚Üí NVIDIA‚Äù

To understand how these three companies interrelate, start with the key nodes in the AI chip value chain:

ASML ‚Äî The Photolithography Monopolist

Section titled ‚ÄúASML ‚Äî The Photolithography Monopolist‚Äù
  • World‚Äôs only supplier of EUV lithography equipment
  • Each EUV system sells for >$200M; the latest High‚ÄëNA EUV is ~$380M per unit
  • All advanced‚Äënode manufacturers (TSMC, Samsung, Intel) depend heavily on ASML

TSMC ‚Äî The King of Advanced Foundry

Section titled ‚ÄúTSMC ‚Äî The King of Advanced Foundry‚Äù
  • 61% global foundry share; 67% share in advanced nodes (<7nm)
  • Chips from all top AI designers (NVIDIA, Apple, AMD, etc.) are manufactured by TSMC
  • Mass‚Äëproduction at 3nm; 2nm in progress

NVIDIA ‚Äî The AI Chip Design Leader

Section titled ‚ÄúNVIDIA ‚Äî The AI Chip Design Leader‚Äù
  • ~$4.38T market cap; data‚Äëcenter business is ~88% of revenue
  • Relies entirely on TSMC‚Äôs advanced nodes to produce H100, H200, and the new Blackwell series
  • Blackwell generated ~$11B in FY25 Q4 revenue alone ‚Äî the ‚Äúfastest product ramp‚Äù in company history

The transmission goes: ASML‚Äôs EUV tools ‚Üí TSMC‚Äôs advanced‚Äënode capacity ‚Üí NVIDIA‚Äôs AI chip supply. A bottleneck at any node constrains the entire chain.

Data: Stock‚ÄëPerformance and Results Correlations

Section titled ‚ÄúData: Stock‚ÄëPerformance and Results Correlations‚Äù

Analyzing post‚Äëearnings stock moves for these three from 2022‚Äì2025 reveals important patterns:

Finding 1: TSMC‚Äôs Link to NVIDIA Is Tighter

Section titled ‚ÄúFinding 1: TSMC‚Äôs Link to NVIDIA Is Tighter‚Äù

Our statistics show:

  • In the 10 trading days after TSMC earnings, NVIDIA‚Äôs return correlation is 0.70 (p=0.004) ‚Äî statistically significant
  • After ASML earnings, NVIDIA‚Äôs 10‚Äëday correlation is 0.49 (p=0.065) ‚Äî weaker
  • Over 30‚Äëday windows, TSMC‚ÜîNVIDIA correlation stays ~0.48; ASML drops to ~0.13

This supports the intuition that the nearer the link in the chain, the stronger the co‚Äëmovement. As NVIDIA‚Äôs direct supplier, TSMC‚Äôs capacity and process progress directly shape how many chips NVIDIA can ship.

Finding 2: Supplier Earnings Tend to Lift NVIDIA

Section titled ‚ÄúFinding 2: Supplier Earnings Tend to Lift NVIDIA‚Äù

On average:

  • In the 10 days after ASML reports, NVIDIA rose 3.8%; over 30 days, +14.2%
  • In the 10 days after TSMC reports, NVIDIA rose 2.1%; over 30 days, +15.8%
  • The effect was most pronounced in 2023 (the breakout year for AI): post‚ÄëASML 30‚Äëday average +19.8%; post‚ÄëTSMC +26.7%

Finding 3: Correlations Weakened in 2024‚Äì2025 but Remain Meaningful

Section titled ‚ÄúFinding 3: Correlations Weakened in 2024‚Äì2025 but Remain Meaningful‚Äù

As NVIDIA‚Äôs market cap surpassed $3T, its stock began to reflect more macro factors:

  • Fed policy expectations
  • U.S. export‚Äëcontrol policy toward China
  • Competition (AMD; hyperscaler in‚Äëhouse chips)

Even so, supplier earnings remain pivotal indicators for NVIDIA ‚Äî especially TSMC‚Äôs expansion plans and ASML‚Äôs EUV shipment cadence, which map to NVIDIA‚Äôs potential shipments over the next 12‚Äì18 months.

Share‚ÄëPrice Performance Comparison

Section titled ‚ÄúShare‚ÄëPrice Performance Comparison‚Äù

NVIDIA vs. ASML vs. TSMC since early 2022 (indexed to 100 at Jan 2022)

The chart shows NVIDIA up 497%, TSMC up 137%, and ASML up 27% over the period. The gap reflects differences in value capture:

  • NVIDIA: commands the highest value‚Äëadded layer via CUDA software ecosystem and leading chip design
  • TSMC: manufacturing profits are high (‚âà60% gross margin) but massive capex tempers stock elasticity
  • ASML: EUV monopoly, but the customer base is limited (principally TSMC, Samsung, Intel) and deliveries are long‚Äëcycle, making growth steadier

Earnings‚ÄëSeason by Year: Who Leads?

Section titled ‚ÄúEarnings‚ÄëSeason by Year: Who Leads?‚Äù
YearNVIDIA ReturnASML ReturnTSMC Return
2022-51.5%-31.5%-42.2%
2023+245.8%+37.7%+40.5%
2024+178.8%-3.3%+94.5%
2025 (YTD)+33.9%+45.7%+54.3%

Key observations:

  • 2022 bear market: all three fell sharply; ASML fell least, showing defensiveness
  • 2023 ‚ÄúAI year one‚Äù: NVIDIA +246%; TSMC and ASML more moderate (+38‚Äì41%)
  • 2024 divergence: NVIDIA +179%; TSMC +95%; ASML ‚àí3% ‚Äî reflecting China‚Äërelated limits and macro concerns
  • 2025 YTD: first time all three are rising together; TSMC/ASML outpacing NVIDIA as markets re‚Äërate upstream value

Three Key Signals from This Earnings Season

Section titled ‚ÄúThree Key Signals from This Earnings Season‚Äù

Signal 1: ASML‚Äôs 2026 Stance Flips 180 Degrees

Section titled ‚ÄúSignal 1: ASML‚Äôs 2026 Stance Flips 180 Degrees‚Äù

In July 2024 (Q2), ASML cautioned that ‚Äúgiven rising macro and geopolitical uncertainty, we cannot confirm growth in 2026,‚Äù triggering a ~16% single‚Äëday drop.

In Q3, management stated clearly that ‚Äú2026 total revenue will not be below 2025,‚Äù stressing enduring AI‚Äëdriven demand. Drivers include:

  • Strong EUV orders: ‚Ç¨5.4B net bookings in Q3, with ‚Ç¨3.6B from EUV
  • High‚ÄëNA EUV shipments have begun, at higher price points (~$380M/unit)
  • TSMC, Samsung, Intel are all expanding; photolithography demand remains robust

Signal 2: TSMC Lifts 2025 Full‚ÄëYear Growth from 30% to 35%

Section titled ‚ÄúSignal 2: TSMC Lifts 2025 Full‚ÄëYear Growth from 30% to 35%‚Äù

In Q3, TSMC raised its 2025 USD revenue‚Äëgrowth outlook from 30% to 35% ‚Äî the second raise this year. CFO Wendell Huang noted: ‚ÄúWe saw strong demand for advanced technologies in Q3, and as we enter Q4, we expect the strength to continue.‚Äù

More importantly, TSMC said 3nm and more advanced nodes are fully booked, with customers ‚Äúcompeting for capacity,‚Äù indicating strong demand from NVIDIA, Apple, and others.

Signal 3: NVIDIA Blackwell Is Supply‚ÄëConstrained; Q4 Guide Above Street

Section titled ‚ÄúSignal 3: NVIDIA Blackwell Is Supply‚ÄëConstrained; Q4 Guide Above Street‚Äù

While NVIDIA has not yet reported Q3 (due Nov 19), Q2 already showed a rapid Blackwell ramp:

  • Q2 Blackwell revenue +17% q/q
  • Q3 guide $54.0B (¬±2%), above the Street‚Äôs $52.7B
  • CEO Jensen Huang: ‚ÄúBlackwell demand is surprising‚Ä¶ we have achieved large‚Äëscale mass production of Blackwell AI supercomputers.‚Äù

UBS lifted its Blackwell Q4 revenue estimate from $5B to $9B, signaling demand far above prior expectations.

Forecast: NVIDIA‚Äôs Q3 and the Road Ahead

Section titled ‚ÄúForecast: NVIDIA‚Äôs Q3 and the Road Ahead‚Äù

Based on supplier prints and historical correlations, we estimate:

Q3 (reports Nov 19)

Section titled ‚ÄúQ3 (reports Nov 19)‚Äù
  • Revenue: consensus $54.0B; we see a modest beat to $54.5‚Äì55.0B
  • Data‚Äëcenter revenue: $47‚Äì48B (‚âà88‚Äì89% mix)
  • Gross margin: 73‚Äì74%, a touch above Q2‚Äôs 72.7%
  • Q4 guide: $60‚Äì65B as Blackwell continues to ramp

Stock outlook

Section titled ‚ÄúStock outlook‚Äù

Near term (1 month post‚Äëprint): if results land near expectations, shares could test the $200‚Äì210 range (‚âà11‚Äì17% above the current ~$180).

Through 2025 year‚Äëend: Street average target ~$222 (+23%).

Upside case: if Blackwell capacity and demand both exceed expectations, HSBC‚Äôs $320 target is conceivable (+78%).

Key risks

Section titled ‚ÄúKey risks‚Äù
  • Macro slowdown: weaker global growth could curb enterprise IT spending
  • Rising competition: AMD‚Äôs MI300 and hyperscaler in‚Äëhouse silicon (Google TPU, Amazon Trainium) chip away at share
  • Geopolitics: tighter U.S. export controls on China
  • Valuation pressure: current ~51x P/E sits well above the market average

Investment Takeaways: Positioning for the AI Chip Chain

Section titled ‚ÄúInvestment Takeaways: Positioning for the AI Chip Chain‚Äù

Core holding: NVIDIA

Section titled ‚ÄúCore holding: NVIDIA‚Äù
  • Strengths: clear technology lead and a moat built on CUDA‚Äôs software ecosystem
  • Valuation: ~51x P/E not trivial, but ~1.3 PEG (on 35‚Äì40% growth) remains reasonable
  • Allocation: core position, ~50‚Äì60% of an AI‚Äëtheme sleeve

Quality anchor: TSMC

Section titled ‚ÄúQuality anchor: TSMC‚Äù
  • Strengths: leading advanced‚Äënode manufacturing; diversified blue‚Äëchip customers (Apple, NVIDIA, AMD, etc.); hard to replace
  • Valuation: ~33.6x P/E, below NVIDIA; PEG < 1 ‚Äî attractive
  • Allocation: primary holding for balanced profiles, ~30‚Äì40%

Defensive ballast: ASML

Section titled ‚ÄúDefensive ballast: ASML‚Äù
  • Strengths: absolute EUV monopoly; high long‚Äëterm visibility
  • Weaknesses: slower growth; more sensitive to macro cycles; sold off in 2024 on China concerns
  • Allocation: defensive weight, ~10‚Äì20%

Note: Mind the transmission lags along the chain

Section titled ‚ÄúNote: Mind the transmission lags along the chain‚Äù

Our work suggests ASML/TSMC earnings impact NVIDIA with lag:

  • Short term (‚â§10 days): higher correlations, smaller absolute moves
  • Medium term (~30 days): weaker correlation, larger cumulative moves
  • Longer term (quarterly): all three converge toward fundamentals

Hence we do not recommend short‚Äëterm trading purely on supplier reports; focus on multi‚Äëquarter trends.

Conclusion: The Acceleration of AI Acceleration Is Just Beginning

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion: The Acceleration of AI Acceleration Is Just Beginning‚Äù

ASML and TSMC‚Äôs Q3 beats are not only their own victories; they‚Äôre also barometers of supply‚Äëchain health. As TSMC‚Äôs CFO put it, ‚ÄúWe continue to see strong AI‚Äërelated demand, and we expect the trend to extend into 2026.‚Äù

Historically, NVIDIA has risen an average 15.8% in the 30 days post‚ÄëTSMC earnings, and 14.2% after ASML. With both suppliers beating this season, NVIDIA enters its Q3 report with a constructive setup.

For investors, the AI chip chain presents a rare case of full‚Äëchain resonance: upstream ASML orderbooks are full; midstream TSMC is running flat out; downstream NVIDIA demand remains robust. In this backdrop, the acceleration of AI acceleration may be only getting started.

Risk Disclaimer: Investing involves risk. This article is for reference only and does not constitute investment advice.

  • Finance
