  • ASML
  • Semiconductor
  • GPU

How ChatGPT Helps Fix Bluetooth Device UI Chaos

Oct 16, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Scenario recap: You built a mobile app that scans nearby BLE devices. Your office/ward/desk is full of the same model, all with the same name. The scan results keep ‚Äújumping‚Äù as new devices arrive; just as users tap one, it gets pushed away ‚Äî pure frustration for a PM.

This article doesn‚Äôt go into protocol internals. Instead, it shows how to use ChatGPT as your AI interaction partner: turn complex technical constraints into a UI your team can build, users can understand, and QA can validate.

1) Align on technical boundaries first, then pick the UI

Section titled ‚Äú1) Align on technical boundaries first, then pick the UI‚Äù

For BLE scanning, a few facts directly shape your design:

  • Advertising payload: Useful info includes local name, service UUIDs, manufacturer data, Tx Power, etc. These can help you distinguish devices and filter. They‚Äôre read from the advertisement data structures.
  • iOS does not expose MAC addresses (privacy). Apps receive a CBPeripheral.identifier-style UUID, and it is not guaranteed to be permanently stable. Do not bake ‚Äúdisplay/remember MAC address‚Äù into any cross‚Äëplatform plan. Prefer short codes/manufacturer data from the advertisement as the differentiator.
  • Android can pre-filter and batch callbacks via ScanFilter and ScanSettings (e.g., filter by service UUID/manufacturer data and use setReportDelay for batched dispatch). This dramatically reduces UI jitter.

With these boundaries clear, ChatGPT can propose cross‚Äëplatform interaction patterns that are actionable, not just theory.

2) Break ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tap the right one‚Äù into three solvable UX problems

Section titled ‚Äú2) Break ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tap the right one‚Äù into three solvable UX problems‚Äù

A. Recognition: Too many identical names ‚Äî which one do I pick?

Section titled ‚ÄúA. Recognition: Too many identical names ‚Äî which one do I pick?‚Äù

Solution: Generate a human‚Äërecognizable short label per device.

  • Ask hardware to add a short code in the advertised name or Manufacturer Data (e.g., last 4 digits of S/N or batch + checksum). Surface it as a subtitle: Device Name ¬∑ Short Code 3K7F. This is a common use of BLE advertisement.
  • iOS cannot show MAC: use the short code and/or service signature from the advertisement as the distinguishing factor. Don‚Äôt promise MAC in product specs.

B. Jitter: List jumps as it refreshes; finger misses the target

Section titled ‚ÄúB. Jitter: List jumps as it refreshes; finger misses the target‚Äù

Solution: Decouple ‚Äúdata changes‚Äù from ‚Äúinterface changes‚Äù.

  • Batched callbacks: On Android, enable ScanSettings.Builder#setReportDelay(xxx) so N updates arrive as a batch. Diff‚Äëupdate the list once to reduce item shifts.
  • Freeze interactive zones: When the user long‚Äëpresses or enters multi‚Äëselect, freeze sorting and positions. Only update light fields inside items (e.g., RSSI value). Merge the full refresh after the action. This follows the principle ‚Äúdon‚Äôt let refreshes interrupt the user‚Äôs task‚Äù.

C. Decision load: Too noisy ‚Äî help me narrow scope first

Section titled ‚ÄúC. Decision load: Too noisy ‚Äî help me narrow scope first‚Äù

Solution: Put filter controls where the hand is.

  • Use Filter/Assist Chips above the list for one‚Äëtap toggles like ‚ÄúRecently used only‚Äù, ‚ÄúStrong signal only‚Äù, ‚ÄúConnectable only‚Äù, ‚ÄúTarget service only‚Äù. Chips are made for quick filtering.
  • Make filtering/sorting intent‚Äëaligned ‚Äî avoid large jumps that break focus. NN/g specifically recommends minimizing ‚Äúview jumping‚Äù when applying filters.

3) A ready‚Äëto‚Äëship UI package for PMs (via ChatGPT)

Section titled ‚Äú3) A ready‚Äëto‚Äëship UI package for PMs (via ChatGPT)‚Äù

You can paste the following to ChatGPT to polish copy, generate a prototype (describe it), or output component and acceptance lists.

(1) List item anatomy

Section titled ‚Äú(1) List item anatomy‚Äù
  • Title: Device name (append batch/model if names collide)
  • Subtitle: Short code ¬∑ Service overview (e.g., 3K7F ¬∑ Battery, UpdateSvc)
  • Right‚Äëside info: RSSI (supports the ‚Äútap the one you‚Äôre close to‚Äù mental model; if showing distance, prefer coarse buckets strong/medium/weak to avoid misleading precision)
  • Status badges: Recently used / New device (reduces decision cost). Use small badges or Chips (MD3).

(2) Top‚Äëlevel quick filters (Chips)

Section titled ‚Äú(2) Top‚Äëlevel quick filters (Chips)‚Äù
  • Recently used only, Strong signal only (> ‚àí70 dBm), Connectable only, Target service only
  • Interaction policy: Keep the viewport stable on toggle. Try not to move the currently focused item.

(3) Sorting and grouping (avoid the alphabetical trap)

Section titled ‚Äú(3) Sorting and grouping (avoid the alphabetical trap)‚Äù
  • Default: Sort by last interaction time descending (user mental model: the thing I just used should be first).
  • Alternative: Group into Recently used / New devices, then sort within groups by RSSI or last seen time. As NN/g notes, alphabetical sorting is rarely the best choice for decision tasks.

(4) Refresh and selection stability

Section titled ‚Äú(4) Refresh and selection stability‚Äù
  • Combine Android batched callbacks with list diffing. When entering multi‚Äëselect/long‚Äëpress, freeze ordering; only ‚Äúlight‚Äëupdate‚Äù fields inside items (e.g., RSSI).

(5) Cross‚Äëplatform identifier strategy

Section titled ‚Äú(5) Cross‚Äëplatform identifier strategy‚Äù
  • Android: Use MAC (when available) or the advertised short code.
  • iOS: Use CBPeripheral.identifier plus advertised short code/service signature. Do not commit to displaying/remembering MAC.

4) Copy and naming you can drop in (EN/CN hints + field names)

Section titled ‚Äú4) Copy and naming you can drop in (EN/CN hints + field names)‚Äù

Group headers (UI copy)

  • Recently Used Devices / ÊúÄËøë‰ΩøÁî®ËøáÁöÑËÆæÂ§á
  • New Devices / Êñ∞ËÆæÂ§á

Filter chips (UI copy)

  • Recently used / Âè™ÁúãÊúÄËøë‰ΩøÁî®
  • Strong signal only (> ‚àí70 dBm) / Âè™ÁúãÂº∫‰ø°Âè∑Ôºà> ‚àí70 dBmÔºâ
  • Connectable only / Âè™ÁúãÂèØËøûÊé•
  • Target service only / Âè™ÁúãÁõÆÊ†áÊúçÂä°

Interfaces/fields (snake_case)

5) Turn ‚Äúplan ‚Üí artifacts‚Äù with ChatGPT

Section titled ‚Äú5) Turn ‚Äúplan ‚Üí artifacts‚Äù with ChatGPT‚Äù

Feed the ‚Äúrequirements + components‚Äù above to ChatGPT and ask for:

  • Prototype description for design: item hierarchy, chip interactions, empty‚Äëstate copy.
  • Engineering checklist: Android ScanFilter/ScanSettings config (with setReportDelay examples), iOS CoreBluetooth scanning and identifier usage cautions.
  • Acceptance cases: With 30+ devices, fluctuating RSSI, and stacked filters, can users still reliably select the intended device?

6) Takeaways: Know the boundaries, design the right interactions

Section titled ‚Äú6) Takeaways: Know the boundaries, design the right interactions‚Äù
  • Lean on advertisement data to distinguish devices; don‚Äôt insist on MAC on iOS.
  • Use batched dispatch + frozen ordering to tame list jitter.
  • Make filtering/sorting intent‚Äëcentric with lightweight Chips; surface ‚ÄúRecently used/New‚Äù to lower selection cost.

With these constraints and patterns in hand, ChatGPT becomes your on‚Äëcall interaction consultant ‚Äî bridging what‚Äôs buildable with what users grasp ‚Äî turning the tiny pain of ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt tap it‚Äù into a chance for a big UX upgrade.

Tags:
  • AI
  • ChatGPT
  • OpenAI
  • Product Manager
  • UX
  • Bluetooth
  • BLE

Oracle Teams Up with AMD: Outlook and Risks for AI‚ÄëEra Stock Performance

Oct 15, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Background: Exploding AI Compute Demand Drives Big‚ÄëTech Collaboration

Section titled ‚ÄúBackground: Exploding AI Compute Demand Drives Big‚ÄëTech Collaboration‚Äù

On October 14, Oracle and AMD announced a plan to build an ultra‚Äëscale AI super‚Äëcluster. Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) will begin deploying 50,000 AMD Instinct MI450 GPUs in Q3 2026, with further expansion expected through 2027 and beyond. This would make Oracle the first hyperscaler to adopt AMD‚Äôs newest GPUs at scale for external AI compute services. According to launch details, each MI450 provides up to 432 GB of HBM4 and 20 TB/s memory bandwidth, enabling models roughly 50% larger than the prior generation to fit fully in memory.

Oracle‚Äôs move targets the explosive growth in compute needs for next‚Äëgeneration AI models. Building on years of collaboration with AMD (OCI has offered MI300X services since 2024), Oracle aims to provide enterprise customers with a high‚Äëperformance, scalable platform for AI training and inference using an open architecture and the latest hardware.

Beyond technology, markets view this as a strategic play to seize share in the AI wave. Oracle increasingly positions AI as its cloud growth engine. CEO Safra Catz expects OCI revenue to surge 77% YoY to $18B this fiscal year and sees potential to reach $144B over the next four years. Against this backdrop, Oracle is tightening its partnership with AMD to pre‚Äëbuild next‚Äëgen AI infrastructure ‚Äî a move with major upside but meaningful execution and market risks.

GPU Market Landscape: Nvidia Dominates, AMD Is Catching Up

Section titled ‚ÄúGPU Market Landscape: Nvidia Dominates, AMD Is Catching Up‚Äù

Today, Nvidia supplies over 90% of high‚Äëperformance AI GPUs used globally. Most hyperscalers ‚Äî Google, Amazon, Microsoft ‚Äî train AI primarily on Nvidia GPUs and the CUDA software stack. However, rising demand for a second source and more open alternatives is creating opportunity for challengers like AMD.

AMD has invested heavily in data‚Äëcenter GPUs. Its Instinct line (e.g., MI250, MI300X) has been trialed in supercomputers and cloud, though historically lagging Nvidia on ecosystem depth and some performance metrics. The new MI450 is a step‚Äëchange in memory capacity and bandwidth, paired with the open ROCm stack, aiming to offer a competitive, more open alternative to Nvidia‚Äôs H100/H200.

Other chipmakers are also pursuing AI acceleration. Broadcom reportedly partnered with OpenAI on custom accelerators, sending Broadcom‚Äôs stock up ~10% on the news. Intel‚Äôs Gaudi series (via Habana) targets value with competitive price‚Äëperformance. The hardware landscape is diversifying as leading AI firms sign multi‚Äëvendor deals.

Price and supply are critical. Nvidia‚Äôs flagship H100 has traded at $30,000‚Äì$40,000 per unit (peaking higher during shortages). Reports suggest AMD has priced MI300 series more aggressively (around ~$10,000 for large customers). Intel markets Gaudi at roughly half the cost of Nvidia alternatives. Hyperscalers are incentivized to diversify for cost control, creating an opening for AMD ‚Äî though potentially at lower margins.

Bottom line: Nvidia remains dominant near term, but AMD‚Äôs technical progress and alliances should lift its share over the next few years.

Cloud Competition: Oracle‚Äôs Opportunities and Challenges

Section titled ‚ÄúCloud Competition: Oracle‚Äôs Opportunities and Challenges‚Äù

Oracle is a relative latecomer to cloud vs. AWS, Azure, and GCP. The AI surge, however, is a chance to move faster: many enterprises want to train large models and deploy generative AI but face tight GPU supply, high costs, and single‚Äëvendor risk on mainstream clouds. Oracle‚Äôs bet on massive AMD GPU clusters aims to differentiate with open standards and better price‚Äëperformance, while attracting multi‚Äëcloud customers who don‚Äôt want to rely on a single provider.

Oracle‚Äôs ‚ÄúAll‚Äëin on AI‚Äù strategy is already yielding big wins. Since 2023, Oracle has secured multiple multi‚Äëbillion‚Äëdollar AI cloud contracts. Market chatter has also suggested a five‚Äëyear, up‚Äëto‚Äë$300B agreement with OpenAI to co‚Äëbuild 4.5 GW of data‚Äëcenter capacity ‚Äî reportedly the largest cloud contract ever. While not officially disclosed, these reports spurred investor optimism; when the rumor emerged in September, Oracle‚Äôs stock jumped ~25% after hours.

Even setting giant deals aside, AI demand is driving OCI‚Äôs guidance higher: this year, Oracle raised its OCI growth outlook from 70% to 77%. Founder Larry Ellison said ‚ÄúAI changes everything,‚Äù and expects AI to materially expand cloud demand in coming years. On the application layer, Oracle plans ‚ÄúAI Database‚Äù offerings that integrate models like ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini directly into Oracle Database to simplify enterprise access ‚Äî a classic Oracle strength that could complement its underlying compute build‚Äëout.

Challenges remain. The Big Three clouds are not standing still: AWS continues to procure Nvidia GPUs and expand Trainium/Inferentia; Azure is tied closely with OpenAI and works with multiple silicon partners; Google has TPUs plus Nvidia options. Competing with established ecosystems and deep capital pools is hard. Meanwhile, buying 50,000 GPUs entails massive capex and technical risk; if AI demand slows or customers underutilize capacity, Oracle could be left with excess.

Net: Oracle‚Äôs AI‚Äëcloud push is a high‚Äërisk, high‚Äëreward wager ‚Äî one that could materially expand its cloud footprint and share price if executed well.

Near Term (6 Months): Elevated Sentiment, Likely Consolidation

Section titled ‚ÄúNear Term (6 Months): Elevated Sentiment, Likely Consolidation‚Äù

Into the next six months (through 1H 2026), Oracle and AMD shares should track sentiment and quarterly prints. Both have rallied strongly on AI narratives: by mid‚ÄëOctober, AMD shares were up ~85% YTD, near all‚Äëtime highs; Oracle was up ~80% YTD. AMD popped 24% in a day after announcing an OpenAI partnership, adding ~$63B in market cap ‚Äî a sign of heightened expectations around AMD‚Äôs AI trajectory.

Short term, that enthusiasm likely needs digestion. Some positives (e.g., Oracle‚ÄìAMD collaboration) are already priced in, and investors may wait for tangible results. Macro variables (rates, growth data) can also add volatility.

If AMD‚Äôs next couple of quarters show data‚Äëcenter momentum (e.g., MI300X traction), the AI story strengthens. But before MI450 volume ramps, revenue impact may remain limited and expectations‚Äëdriven, implying higher share‚Äëprice beta.

Net: expect range‚Äëbound trading at elevated levels, with newsflow (partnerships, product launches, conference commentary) driving swings until fundamentals catch up.

Midterm (1 Year): Turning Partnerships into Revenue

Section titled ‚ÄúMidterm (1 Year): Turning Partnerships into Revenue‚Äù

Looking 12 months out (into 2H 2026), Oracle‚ÄìAMD cooperation should start bearing fruit. Q3 2026 is the target window for Oracle‚Äôs MI450‚Äëbased super‚Äëcluster to come online and begin serving customers. That‚Äôs when early investment can begin converting to revenue:

‚Ä¢ For AMD: Deliveries of 50,000 MI450s would contribute significant sales. Its OpenAI partnership is slated to begin deployments (reportedly ~1 GW in late 2026, growing to ~6 GW over several years). Management and sell‚Äëside views suggest these mega‚Äëorders could add ‚Äútens of billions‚Äù in new revenue over time and boost EPS materially ‚Äî assuming successful production ramp and on‚Äëspec performance.

‚Ä¢ For Oracle: AI compute capacity will step up materially with MI450 clusters in production, complementing earlier MI300X/MI355X services. Key AI customer wins should begin to contribute. If rumored mega‚Äëdeals prove out, fiscal 2027 could see step‚Äëfunction growth, with the market likely to pre‚Äëprice part of that in 2026.

Execution and competition are the key risks: AMD must hit schedules and targets; Oracle must convert capacity into sticky workloads amidst aggressive rivals.

Long Term (3 Years): Industry Reshaping with High Uncertainty

Section titled ‚ÄúLong Term (3 Years): Industry Reshaping with High Uncertainty‚Äù

By ~2028, AI/GPU/cloud dynamics could look very different. The opportunity set is large, but so are the uncertainties:

‚Ä¢ AMD Upside: If partnerships execute, AMD could emerge as a major AI‚Äëaccelerator supplier by 2027‚Äì2028, with data‚Äëcenter GPUs becoming a multi‚Äëbillion‚Äëdollar pillar. In a bullish case, AMD could reach 20%‚Äì30% share in AI accelerators.

‚Ä¢ AMD Risks: Technology cycles are fast. Nvidia‚Äôs Blackwell (2025‚Äì2026) and potential advances (e.g., GPU+CPU+optical interconnects) may extend its lead. AMD must sustain heavy R&D to keep pace in architecture and software ecosystems.

‚Ä¢ Oracle Upside: If Oracle becomes a top‚Äëtier AI compute provider through deep wins with customers like OpenAI, its cloud scale and reputation could rise significantly by 2028.

‚Ä¢ Oracle Risks: The AI cloud could bifurcate into a few giants or devolve into price wars. If AWS/Azure extend leads, Oracle‚Äôs share gains could remain limited.

Opportunities and Risks: Summary

Section titled ‚ÄúOpportunities and Risks: Summary‚Äù

Key Opportunities

  1. Explosive AI demand expands the total addressable market.
  2. Flagship collaborations can lift market share and revenue visibility.
  3. A more diversified silicon ecosystem (beyond Nvidia) reduces single‚Äëvendor risk.
  4. Underlying business trends for both Oracle and AMD are favorable.

Key Risks

  1. Intense competition and fast product cycles.
  2. Execution risk (R&D, yield, delivery, software ecosystem).
  3. Macro and regulatory headwinds.
  4. Valuation and bubble risk after sharp rallies.

Conclusion: Stock‚ÄëPrice Outlook

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion: Stock‚ÄëPrice Outlook‚Äù

Oracle and AMD are leaning into the AI infrastructure super‚Äëcycle. If they execute, both could convert surging compute demand and a more open, multi‚Äëvendor landscape into durable growth and shareholder returns. Over six months, sentiment and newsflow likely dominate. Over a year, delivery milestones and contract conversions become the key drivers. Over three years, the winners will be those who ship reliably at scale while maintaining strong ecosystems and cost profiles.

This report is based on publicly available information and does not constitute investment advice. Markets are risky; please invest prudently.

Tags:
  • Finance
  • US Market
  • Investment
  • Oracle
  • AMD
  • AI
  • GPU
  • Cloud Computing

Q3 2025 U.S. Bank Earnings: Market Correlations and AI Outlook

Oct 15, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Key Findings: Banks Closely Track the Broad Market

Section titled ‚ÄúKey Findings: Banks Closely Track the Broad Market‚Äù

Based on historical data from Oct 2020 through Oct 2025, U.S. bank stocks exhibit a pronounced positive correlation with the major indices. The daily‚Äëreturn correlation between the Financials ETF (XLF) and the S&P 500 is 0.789 ‚Äî a strong positive relationship. Practically, bank shares tend to move in tandem with the broader market, though the link is not perfect and retains some independence.

By comparison, the correlation between bank stocks and the Nasdaq is lower at 0.626, reflecting structural differences between Financials and the tech‚Äëheavy Nasdaq. Notably, the correlation between the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq is as high as 0.951, indicating very tight co‚Äëmovement between the two benchmarks.

Earnings‚ÄëSeason Impact Pattern

Section titled ‚ÄúEarnings‚ÄëSeason Impact Pattern‚Äù

Analyzing the bank‚Äëearnings windows across 21 quarters over the past five years (the 5 trading days before and after each earnings release) reveals a few consistent patterns:

Directional synchronicity

Section titled ‚ÄúDirectional synchronicity‚Äù

Following bank earnings, Financials and the S&P 500 moved in the same direction 71.4% of the time; the synchronicity rate with the Nasdaq was 66.7%. Bank earnings thus tend to exert a notable directional influence on the overall market.

Return characteristics

Section titled ‚ÄúReturn characteristics‚Äù

In the five trading days after earnings, Financials rose an average of 0.49%, slightly ahead of the S&P 500‚Äôs 0.09% and the Nasdaq‚Äôs ‚àí0.19%. Strong bank results typically provide the most direct uplift to the Financials sector, with a comparatively smaller spillover to tech.

Year‚Äëto‚Äëyear differences

Section titled ‚ÄúYear‚Äëto‚Äëyear differences‚Äù

The pattern varies by year. In 2022, post‚Äëearnings performance was the strongest (Financials gained an average of 2.47% over the 5 days following reports), while 2020‚Äì2021 and 2025 saw negative returns ‚Äî a reflection of shifting macro backdrops and sentiment.

Recent Q3 2025 Bank Results and Market Reaction

Section titled ‚ÄúRecent Q3 2025 Bank Results and Market Reaction‚Äù

From Oct 14‚Äì15, 2025, large banks including JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, Wells Fargo, and BlackRock reported Q3 results, broadly beating expectations. Highlights include:

  • JPMorgan: revenue +9% to $47.1B; net income +12% to $14.4B; investment‚Äëbanking revenue +17%
  • Goldman Sachs: net income +37% to $4.1B; investment‚Äëbanking revenue +42%; M&A advisory +60%
  • Citigroup: revenue +9% to $22.1B; investment‚Äëbanking revenue +34%

Strength was driven primarily by resurgent investment‚Äëbanking activity and elevated trading. A record‚Äësetting quarter for equities and warming M&A supported the backdrop. Still, despite impressive prints, JPMorgan and Goldman shares fell 3.8% and 5.0% on the day, respectively ‚Äî a reminder that elevated expectations and valuation can cap near‚Äëterm reactions.

Five‚ÄëYear Context

Section titled ‚ÄúFive‚ÄëYear Context‚Äù

From Oct 2020 to Oct 2025, Financials (XLF) posted cumulative gains of 119.09%, outpacing the S&P 500‚Äôs 99.23% and the Nasdaq‚Äôs 104.70%. By year:

  • 2021: Financials led with +34.28%, aided by recovery momentum and rising‚Äërate expectations
  • 2022: broad declines; Financials ‚àí13.48%, still better than the Nasdaq‚Äôs ‚àí33.89%
  • 2023: tech rebound; the Nasdaq surged +44.52%, while Financials rose +9.56%
  • 2024‚Äì2025: Financials continued to outperform amid evolving rate dynamics

Outlook: Q4 2025 Into 2026

Section titled ‚ÄúOutlook: Q4 2025 Into 2026‚Äù

S&P 500 and Nasdaq targets

Section titled ‚ÄúS&P 500 and Nasdaq targets‚Äù

Street targets skew cautiously optimistic into year‚Äëend:

  • Goldman Sachs: S&P 500 YE target 6,800 (~2% upside vs. current), and 6,900 for 2026
  • JPMorgan: YE range 6,000‚Äì6,500, cautious stance
  • BMO Capital: 7,000 ‚Äî among the most bullish
  • Morgan Stanley: YE 6,500; warns U.S.‚ÄìChina trade escalation could drive an ~11% pullback

Analysts broadly see an expected ~8% Q3 earnings growth (which would mark a ninth consecutive quarter if achieved) as a core support. Fed easing expectations, AI‚Äëdriven tech growth, and corporate profit resilience sit behind the constructive bias.

Risks remain: the S&P 500 trades at 22.8x earnings ‚Äî above the 5‚Äëyr average (19.9x) and 10‚Äëyr average (18.6x). Market cap concentration is elevated: roughly 40% sits in 10 ‚Äúsuper‚Äëstocks,‚Äù leaving less margin for error if leaders stumble.

AI Sector Deep Dive

Section titled ‚ÄúAI Sector Deep Dive‚Äù

AI leaders should continue to drive index performance, though growth rates likely moderate from prior peaks:

NVIDIA

Section titled ‚ÄúNVIDIA‚Äù

FY2025 revenue reached $130.5B, up 114% y/y, with Q4 revenue at $39.3B. FY2026 Q1 revenue was $44.1B (+69% y/y, decelerating). The Blackwell architecture contributed ~$11B in Q4 revenue ‚Äî dubbed the ‚Äúfastest product ramp‚Äù in NVIDIA‚Äôs history. Consensus points to FY2026 revenue around $198.8B and EPS of $4.32. Despite slower growth, NVIDIA retains ~80% share in AI accelerators.

Microsoft

Section titled ‚ÄúMicrosoft‚Äù

In FY2025 Q4, Azure‚Äôs annualized revenue run‚Äërate topped $75B (+39% y/y). The company guides record ~$30B capex in FY2026 Q1 for AI infrastructure. Intelligent Cloud is expected to grow 25‚Äì26%, with Azure (ex‚Äësome items) at ~37%. Microsoft Copilot MAUs surpassed 100M. Some analysts expect Microsoft could become the first $5T company.

Google and Amazon

Section titled ‚ÄúGoogle and Amazon‚Äù

Google Cloud Q2 revenue was $13.6B (+32% y/y), with a 20.7% operating margin; GCP (infrastructure) is estimated growing near 40%. AWS Q2 revenue was $30.9B (+17.5% y/y) but supply‚Äëconstrained. Anthropic is a flagship customer, and AWS is building >1 GW of data‚Äëcenter capacity to support AI demand.

Capex trends

Section titled ‚ÄúCapex trends‚Äù

The turning point: analysts expect cloud capex growth to slow meaningfully in 2026. Goldman sees growth stepping down from 54% (2025) to 26%; Morgan Stanley to 16%; Evercore to 18%. The deceleration reflects rising depreciation and return‚Äëpressure. Amazon and Google are expected to decelerate the most (~11% slower), while Meta may sustain ~42% growth.

AI market size

Section titled ‚ÄúAI market size‚Äù

The global AI market is projected to grow from $294.2B in 2025 to $1.77T by 2032 (29.2% CAGR). That underpins a durable multi‚Äëyear theme, but in the near term investors should watch how capex deceleration affects AI‚Äëinfrastructure valuations.

Investment Implications and Risks

Section titled ‚ÄúInvestment Implications and Risks‚Äù

Banks

Section titled ‚ÄúBanks‚Äù

Large banks delivered strong Q3 2025 prints, with trading and investment‚Äëbanking as key drivers. However, ongoing Fed cuts could compress net interest margins, weighing on traditional lending profitability. Bank CEOs remain cautious, flagging tariff uncertainty, geopolitics, and consumer credit quality.

AI equities

Section titled ‚ÄúAI equities‚Äù

While AI remains the long‚Äëterm growth engine, consider:

  1. stretched valuations leave limited error tolerance;
  2. slower capex growth could prompt multiple compression in AI infrastructure;
  3. concentration risk around a handful of mega caps.

Diversification into non‚Äëmega‚Äëcap beneficiaries (e.g., AMD, Palantir, select cloud providers) may be a more balanced approach.

Macro risks

Section titled ‚ÄúMacro risks‚Äù

U.S.‚ÄìChina tensions, U.S. government shutdown risk, sticky inflation, and slowing growth could raise volatility. Seasonally, Q4 often brings choppier tape ‚Äî stay alert.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

History suggests bank‚Äëearnings seasons align positively with the broader U.S. market; strong bank prints often support risk appetite. The latest October reports again broadly beat, underscoring sector resilience in today‚Äôs macro mix.

Into the next quarter, we expect modest gains for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, constrained by elevated valuations and macro uncertainty. AI should continue to lead, but with slower growth and capex normalization ‚Äî making selectivity more important and blind chasing of richly valued mega caps less prudent.

Financials have outperformed over the past five years, but 2026 could test durability amid a rate‚Äëcut cycle. Balanced portfolios ‚Äî blending cyclical Financials and secular AI winners while monitoring earnings quality and valuation ‚Äî look prudent.

Note: This report is based on public information and is not investment advice. Markets involve risk; proceed with caution.

  • US Market
