  • Over half of revenue depends on U.S. government contracts.
  • Commercial expansion is slower (roughly 20% growth), falling short of AI‚Äëboom expectations.

4. Insider selling

  • CEO Alex Karp has reportedly sold nearly $2B of stock over two years.
  • Interpreted as wavering confidence and fuels market doubts.

How AI euphoria skews valuation

Section titled ‚ÄúHow AI euphoria skews valuation‚Äù
  • Global AI equities trade around 30√ó forward P/E, well above the S&P 500‚Äôs ~19√ó.
  • Palantir‚Äôs YTD gain exceeded 130% at one point, emblematic of the AI story trade.
  • Investors chase narrative over fundamentals; even Sam Altman has cautioned about bubble signs.

Double‚Äëedged sword:

  • Upside: markets award premium multiples; some dub Palantir the ‚ÄúOracle of AI.‚Äù
  • Risk: when heat fades, multiples can compress quickly.

Latest results and comp table

Section titled ‚ÄúLatest results and comp table‚Äù

Highlights:

  • 2025 Q2 revenue topped $1B for the first time, +48% YoY.
  • U.S. commercial +93% YoY; government +53%.
  • EPS $0.16; operating margin 46.3%; FCF margin 57%.

Valuation comps:

  • Palantir: P/S ~ 80√ó; P/E ~ 200‚Äì300√ó.
  • NVIDIA: P/E ~35√ó.
  • Microsoft/Google: P/E ~30√ó.
  • OpenAI (private): ~$500B valuation, P/S ~17√ó.

üëâ On OpenAI‚Äëstyle multiples, Palantir‚Äôs ‚Äúfair‚Äù price might be around $40, well below spot.

Risks of shorting Palantir

Section titled ‚ÄúRisks of shorting Palantir‚Äù
  • Retail sponsorship: like GameStop, sentiment can squeeze price higher.
  • Low short interest: ~2.5% vs C3.ai‚Äôs ~20%.
  • Headline sensitivity: a big contract or AI milestone can spike shares and squeeze shorts.

Mid‚Äë to long‚Äëterm potential

Section titled ‚ÄúMid‚Äë to long‚Äëterm potential‚Äù

1. Government moat

  • Long relationships with DoD and intelligence agencies; long cycles, large dollars.
  • Latest DoD contract reportedly expanded to $1.3B, running through 2029.

2. Commercial expansion

  • AIP (AI Platform) trials across banking, healthcare, and manufacturing.
  • Q2 added 157 $1M+ contracts ‚Äî clear progress in commercialization.

3. Healthy financial profile

  • High gross margin and strong FCF; multiple profitable quarters.
  • Unlike ‚Äúpure AI concept‚Äù names relying on external financing.

4. Structural tailwinds

  • Rising AI and analytics penetration.
  • Palantir could become the ‚Äúenterprise data operating system.‚Äù
  • Some analysts have lifted targets to $150‚Äì200.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Palantir sits at a controversial crossroads:

  • Bears argue valuation far exceeds fundamentals and will normalize.
  • Bulls point to the government moat and AIP traction, expecting earnings to fill the gap.

Investor takeaway:

  • Beware of bubbles, but don‚Äôt ignore long‚Äëterm potential.
  • Near‚Äëterm volatility is high; both long and short carry risk.
  • Long‚Äërun value will be determined by execution and landing real products.

In the short run, markets are a voting machine; in the long run, a weighing machine. Whether Palantir grows into its valuation will be answered by innovation and results.

Tags:
  • Finance
  • Palantir
  • NYSE: PLTR
  • AI
  • US Stock Market

Adapt Team Management to the AI Era: Turn Personal ‚ÄòAmplifiers‚Äô into Team Defaults

Aug 19, 2025
Vibe Sparking

AI is a personal amplifier. First, use AI to make one ‚Äúlead operator‚Äù self‚Äësustaining; don‚Äôt worship big‚Äëtech resumes; be careful with KPI/OKR idolatry; practice self‚Äëdiscipline to enable others; and remember there is no shortcut. This piece turns those principles into executable team practices.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

AI isn‚Äôt just another tool ‚Äî it multiplies individual firepower. Those who wield it can be ‚Äú1 person doing the work of 10‚Äù; those who don‚Äôt may not even notice the gap widening. Empirical studies show significant productivity gains in writing tasks, and customer support improves by ~14% on average, with larger gains for less experienced workers.

Implication: shift management focus from ‚Äúpolicing process and headcount‚Äù to ‚Äúmanaging leverage and cadence.‚Äù

Eight hard rules to change now

Section titled ‚ÄúEight hard rules to change now‚Äù

1) Make the ‚ÄúAI amplifier‚Äù a default setting

Section titled ‚Äú1) Make the ‚ÄúAI amplifier‚Äù a default setting‚Äù

Set a clear goal: 90% of routine actions have an AI variant. From SOPs, dailies, weekly notes to code reviews and requirement breakdowns ‚Äî always provide a with‚ÄëAI path. Reason: McKinsey estimates $2.6‚Äì$4.4T of annual value from gen‚ÄëAI, compounding labor productivity over time.

2) Build an ‚ÄúAI lead goose,‚Äù then replicate

Section titled ‚Äú2) Build an ‚ÄúAI lead goose,‚Äù then replicate‚Äù

Don‚Äôt train everyone first. Start with 1‚Äì3 lead operators who can run a business slice on AI:

  • A growth thread: lead cleaning, DM automation, landing‚Äëpage A/B.
  • A delivery thread: code+tests generation, doc automation, customer reply drafts. Scale by ‚Äúdemonstrate ‚Üí follow‚Äù to the second wave. Real projects align expectations and shape culture.

3) Evolve performance from ‚Äúoutput volume‚Äù to ‚ÄúAI leverage‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äú3) Evolve performance from ‚Äúoutput volume‚Äù to ‚ÄúAI leverage‚Äù‚Äù

Track three dimensions:

  • Efficiency: cycle‚Äëtime reduction for equivalent tasks with‚ÄëAI.
  • Quality: defect rate/CSAT changes attributable to AI (studies show gains in satisfaction and retention).
  • Reuse: number of reusable prompts, workflows, and templates. Don‚Äôt worship KPI/OKR dashboards. HBR warns metrics divorced from strategy backfire; a common OKR mistake is treating tasks as outcomes.

4) Pragmatic hiring: prioritize ‚ÄúAI‚Äëtransferable ability,‚Äù not logos

Section titled ‚Äú4) Pragmatic hiring: prioritize ‚ÄúAI‚Äëtransferable ability,‚Äù not logos‚Äù

Look for:

  • Translating business problems ‚Üí data/tools ‚Üí executable prompts;
  • Productizing personal workflows (scripts, macros, agents);
  • Ability to teach others (clear SOPs/templates);
  • Basic respect for security/compliance (data classification, red‚Äëline awareness).

5) Structure: ‚Äúsmall squads + toolchains,‚Äù learn by shipping

Section titled ‚Äú5) Structure: ‚Äúsmall squads + toolchains,‚Äù learn by shipping‚Äù

Avoid early over‚Äëhiring. Use 4‚Äì6‚Äëperson squads (PM/eng/data/ops) bound to the same prompt library, KB, and automation scripts. Keep human‚ÄìAI collaboration as assets ‚Äî not screenshots of chats.

6) Process shift: from weekly/monthly reports to replayable workflows and real‚Äëtime metrics

Section titled ‚Äú6) Process shift: from weekly/monthly reports to replayable workflows and real‚Äëtime metrics‚Äù

Reports aren‚Äôt the goal; reproducibility is.

  • Record canonical workflows as agent run + prompts + sample data;
  • Dashboard AI calls per capita, hours saved, reuse rate. As process reproducibility increases, outcomes follow; fixation on outcomes alone often reduces effectiveness. (Industry and research agree: deeper AI integration lifts both value and adoption.)

7) Cultural core: self‚Äëdiscipline to enable others ‚Äî turn anxiety into practice

Section titled ‚Äú7) Cultural core: self‚Äëdiscipline to enable others ‚Äî turn anxiety into practice‚Äù

AI isn‚Äôt a replacement machine; it‚Äôs human augmentation. Stanford‚Äôs takeaway: replace humans with AI and you lose; augment humans with AI and you win. Manager moves:

  • Give ‚Äúerror budgets‚Äù and ‚Äúlearning budgets.‚Äù
  • Default to pair‚Äëprompting so newcomers shorten ramp‚Äëup (evidence shows bigger gains for juniors).

8) Don‚Äôt bet on shortcuts; bet on compounding

Section titled ‚Äú8) Don‚Äôt bet on shortcuts; bet on compounding‚Äù

No magic curves, only compounding curves:

  • Ship one reusable workflow every week;
  • Monthly retro on ‚Äúhours saved and quality held‚Äù;
  • Quarterly cleanup of tech‚Äë and data‚Äëdebt. AI adoption is like fitness ‚Äî consistency compounds. Global data shows rapid enterprise adoption; failure to keep pace is falling behind.

Playbook: six 0‚Üí1 transformations

Section titled ‚ÄúPlaybook: six 0‚Üí1 transformations‚Äù

A. People: three‚Äëlayer capability model

Section titled ‚ÄúA. People: three‚Äëlayer capability model‚Äù
  • Base: AI basics (retrieval, rewriting, structuring, review).
  • Middle: task‚Äëchain orchestration (multi‚Äëturn prompts, tool use, RAG/KB).
  • Top: business agentization (auto‚Äëpull data, auto‚Äëgenerate/execute, auto‚Äëretro). Assessment: from ‚Äúcan use‚Äù to ‚Äúcan teach.‚Äù Promotions reward how many others you uplift.

B. Work: ‚Äúlist ‚Üí template ‚Üí automate‚Äù high‚Äëfrequency tasks

Section titled ‚ÄúB. Work: ‚Äúlist ‚Üí template ‚Üí automate‚Äù high‚Äëfrequency tasks‚Äù

Examples:

  • Pre‚Äësales: inquiry classification ‚Üí auto‚Äëreply drafts ‚Üí CRM ingest ‚Üí next‚Äëtouch reminders.
  • Engineering: requirements ‚Üí cases ‚Üí code ‚Üí tests ‚Üí deploy scaffolds.
  • Support: ticket similarity ‚Üí answer drafts ‚Üí second review ‚Üí FAQ back to KB.

C. Tools: a three‚Äëlayer stack

Section titled ‚ÄúC. Tools: a three‚Äëlayer stack‚Äù
  • Collab: docs/KB/boards.
  • Intelligence: conversational orchestration (workflows/agents), function calling, RAG.
  • Monitoring: cost, quality, compliance, drift alerts. Requirement: everything output is reusable.

D. Data: governance first

Section titled ‚ÄúD. Data: governance first‚Äù

Label data by source, sensitivity, sharing scope, retention. Use de‚Äëidentified samples for training/chat; route outward content via human review + watermark.

E. Performance: define excellence as ‚Äúleverage + learning speed‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúE. Performance: define excellence as ‚Äúleverage + learning speed‚Äù‚Äù

Keep OKRs, but write KRs as measurable AI leverage:

  • KR1: cycle time on key tasks (with‚ÄëAI) ‚àí30% or better.
  • KR2: ‚â•6 reusable workflows/month.
  • KR3: uplift teammate adoption and saved hours. Avoid KRs as task lists (‚ÄúX meetings/Y reports‚Äù).

F. Budget: fund ‚Äúoutput/cost,‚Äù not seat count

Section titled ‚ÄúF. Budget: fund ‚Äúoutput/cost,‚Äù not seat count‚Äù

Spend on high‚Äëreuse scenarios and data hygiene, not raw seats. Prove 3 payback flows before expansion.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

AI‚Äëera management is simple: put an amplifier on everyone‚Äôs back, make every task machine‚Äëreusable, and keep the org steady, clear, and fast. Skip anxiety, skip ‚Äúshortcuts.‚Äù Stack small wins into compounding wins. Which three actions should your team AI‚Äëenable first?

Tags:
  • AI
  • Team Management

A Tech Lead‚Äôs Day in the AI Era

Aug 19, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Don‚Äôt win by ‚Äúhow hard I grind,‚Äù win by ‚Äúhow much harder my team can grind.‚Äù With ChatGPT, Claude, and Gemini in the loop, this schedule runs nearly twice as fast.

07:00 | Info Radar & Community Pulse (light warm‚Äëup)

Section titled ‚Äú07:00 | Info Radar & Community Pulse (light warm‚Äëup)‚Äù

Actions

  • Scan AI updates on X; repost with a one‚Äëline judgment.
  • Collect into a ‚Äúmaterials inbox‚Äù: title, link, one‚Äëline value.
  • Use a custom GPT in ChatGPT as a ‚Äúmorning brief secretary‚Äù to auto‚Äëproduce 3 team‚Äëusable ideas (e.g., PRD leads, data points).

How to implement

  • Create a private GPT with a fixed output schema (source / summary / actionable advice). When needed, enable Advanced Data Analysis to OCR tables in screenshots into CSV.

One‚Äëline prompt

‚ÄúSort these 5 AI news items by impact on our product. For each, give 1 actionable experiment. Output a table.‚Äù

08:00 | Commute launch ritual (prime momentum)

Section titled ‚Äú08:00 | Commute launch ritual (prime momentum)‚Äù

Actions

  • Bring a book; don‚Äôt grind in transit ‚Äî keep cadence steady.
  • Open ChatGPT Voice to dictate a brain‚Äëdump; compress into 3 MITs with acceptance criteria. Voice is smoother than typing.

Voice prompt

‚ÄúHelp me compress today into 3 Most Important Tasks. For each: one sentence + acceptance criteria.‚Äù

09:00 | MIT deep‚Äëwork window (move the progress bar only)

Section titled ‚Äú09:00 | MIT deep‚Äëwork window (move the progress bar only)‚Äù

Actions

  • Small changes: ship yourself; verify by results.
  • Big tasks: delegate, but state ‚Äúgoal + acceptance‚Äù crisply.
  • Use Gemini 1.5 long context: feed long docs/screens, ask for an acceptance checklist only.

One‚Äëline prompt

‚ÄúRead this PRD/user‚Äëfeedback screenshots. Output a checkbox acceptance list (binary ‚Äòpass/fail‚Äô only, no long sentences).‚Äù

10:00 | Coaching‚Äëstyle meeting (less command, more questions)

Section titled ‚Äú10:00 | Coaching‚Äëstyle meeting (less command, more questions)‚Äù

Actions

  • Don‚Äôt grab the steering wheel; follow a ‚Äúcoach 50 minutes‚Äù rule ‚Äî I don‚Äôt jump in, the team grows faster.
  • Do three things only: define boundaries, design the smallest validation, confirm the next milestone.
  • Use Claude Code as a ‚Äúpost‚Äëmeeting reviewer‚Äù: feed notes + code snippets + logs to produce a minimal next‚Äëstep experiment plan.

One‚Äëline prompt

‚ÄúFrom the meeting notes + this code, list two smallest experiments we can independently validate this week, including commands, expected outputs, and rollback conditions.‚Äù

12:00 | 1‚Äëkm walk (reset and long‚Äërange thinking)

Section titled ‚Äú12:00 | 1‚Äëkm walk (reset and long‚Äërange thinking)‚Äù

Actions

  • Write while walking; it stabilizes the mind.
  • Creativity often spikes after walking/exercise; let the subconscious brew.

14:00 | Product QA (trim edges like pruning a tree)

Section titled ‚Äú14:00 | Product QA (trim edges like pruning a tree)‚Äù

Actions

  • Use today‚Äôs build hands‚Äëon; note 10 friction points while using it.
  • With ChatGPT Advanced Data Analysis, compare screenshots/analytics: before/after click paths, latency metrics, crash counts.
  • Send repeated issues to Gemini Code Assist or Claude Code for patch suggestions; use whichever integrates better with your IDE.

One‚Äëline prompt

‚ÄúCompare event CSVs from v1.6 vs v1.7. Show the average time from A to payment, as a table + a short diagnosis.‚Äù

15:00 | Support radar (turn emotions into a roadmap)

Section titled ‚Äú15:00 | Support radar (turn emotions into a roadmap)‚Äù

Actions

  • Watch for tone and closure; push items to GitHub Projects: Issue ‚Üí Owner ‚Üí Due date ‚Üí Linked PR.
  • Use GitHub Actions to automate: when PR is ready, auto‚Äëcreate/label tasks.
  • Use Claude or ChatGPT to draft user replies ‚Äî but you finalize the voice.

One‚Äëline prompt

‚ÄúTurn these 12 support notes into a release update using a four‚Äëpart structure: problem, fix, go‚Äëlive time, impact scope.‚Äù

16:00 | One hour of a hard book (judgment training)

Section titled ‚Äú16:00 | One hour of a hard book (judgment training)‚Äù

Actions

  • Tech leads win on judgment, powered by cross‚Äëdiscipline inputs.
  • Use ChatGPT Memory for long‚Äëterm preferences and study topics; auto‚Äëlink new chats to old notes. You can view/delete/disable memory anytime in settings.

One‚Äëline prompt

‚ÄúFrom my past chats on ‚ÄòAI experience metrics,‚Äô pull the metrics I mentioned and compile a one‚Äëpage comparison (cite each item with the message date).‚Äù

18:00 | Leave on time (anti‚Äëcrunch team cadence)

Section titled ‚Äú18:00 | Leave on time (anti‚Äëcrunch team cadence)‚Äù

Actions

  • Lead by example: keep efficiency in daylight, give evenings back to life.
  • Healthy rhythm sustains output.

19:00 | Dinner & 4‚Äëkm walk (roaming time)

Section titled ‚Äú19:00 | Dinner & 4‚Äëkm walk (roaming time)‚Äù

Actions

  • While walking, use ChatGPT Voice or Gemini Live to dictate ideas ‚Üí convert to todos.
  • Roaming aids creativity; walking‚Äôs boost is supported by research.

20:00 | Community issues / writing / study with kids (variable slot)

Section titled ‚Äú20:00 | Community issues / writing / study with kids (variable slot)‚Äù

Actions

  • Merge patches; backfill tests.
  • If no heavy engineering, write a technical retro ‚Äî invest in team knowledge.
  • Study time: use Claude or ChatGPT to explain solution thinking visually ‚Äî don‚Äôt just give the answer.

One‚Äëline prompt

‚ÄúExplain this function problem in three diagrammed steps ‚Äî Given ‚Üí Transform ‚Üí Substitute & Verify ‚Äî with two‚Äësentence explanations + one common pitfall per step.‚Äù

22:00 | Support retro (attitude first)

Section titled ‚Äú22:00 | Support retro (attitude first)‚Äù

Actions

  • Scan the day‚Äôs 3k+ support messages.
  • Skip good service; log poor cases ‚Üí follow up next morning.
  • Use Gemini API for structured extraction: sentiment, module, severity; export a table for the next stand‚Äëup.

23:00 | Heavy‚Äëbook sleep induction (power down)

Section titled ‚Äú23:00 | Heavy‚Äëbook sleep induction (power down)‚Äù

Actions

  • Read 20 pages; wind down.
  • Sleep when sleepy.

Late night | Idea catcher (3 lines are enough)

Section titled ‚ÄúLate night | Idea catcher (3 lines are enough)‚Äù

Actions

  • Wake and jot three sentences, then sleep.
  • Next day, use ChatGPT/Gemini to expand them into a minimal experiment.

‚ÄúMinimal Executable‚Äù AI checklist (copy‚Äëready)

Section titled ‚Äú‚ÄúMinimal Executable‚Äù AI checklist (copy‚Äëready)‚Äù
  • Morning brief secretary (ChatGPT GPTs): fixed output source / one‚Äëline judgment / actionable experiment, keep historical comparisons.
  • Meeting retro ‚Üí plan (Claude Code): notes + code + logs ‚Üí two smallest experiments.
  • Long docs ‚Üí acceptance list (Gemini 1.5): PRD/charts/screenshots ‚Üí JSON acceptance points.
  • Support ‚Üí Issue ‚Üí PR (GitHub Actions): Ready‚Äëfor‚Äëreview ‚Üí auto‚Äëcreate cards and add to project.
  • Team knowledge backflow (ChatGPT Memory): persist ‚Äúour experience metrics/style conventions‚Äù as long‚Äëterm memory; clear/disable when needed.
Tags:
  • AI
  • Team Management

Frontend AI Perk: Open-Source Open‚ÄëLovable vs. Lovable ‚Äî One‚ÄëClick Clone Any Website into a React App

Aug 14, 2025
Vibe Sparking

For engineers and creators who want to use AI to ship products faster and validate ideas more cost‚Äëeffectively.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Lovable has gone viral recently: you can chat to generate websites/apps, with pricing based on credits. It‚Äôs a fresh model and surprisingly fast. At the same time, the Mendable team released an open-source alternative open‚Äëlovable: clone any website into a modern React app, run it locally, modify it, and extend it. For many teams, this route is more controllable and cost‚Äëefficient.

What is open‚Äëlovable?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat is open‚Äëlovable?‚Äù

In one sentence: Give it a URL, and in seconds it pulls page structure and assets and generates runnable Next.js/React code that you can develop locally. Under the hood it has two ‚Äúengines‚Äù:

  • Firecrawl: crawls web content and converts it into LLM‚Äëfriendly structured data like Markdown/JSON/screenshots.
  • E2B Sandboxes: secure, isolated cloud sandboxes serving as an ‚ÄúAI code runtime,‚Äù letting agents run commands, read/write files, install packages, and access the network.

The official README clearly lists dependencies and steps (supports Anthropic, OpenAI, Gemini, or Groq ‚Äî any/some combination). You‚Äôll need E2B_API_KEY + FIRECRAWL_API_KEY, plus at least one model provider API key. Then npm run dev to try it at localhost:3000. License is MIT.

Key point: open‚Äëlovable leans toward ‚Äúclone + local control,‚Äù while Lovable is more of a ‚Äúhosted AI app builder.‚Äù

What does Lovable do? Why benchmark against it?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat does Lovable do? Why benchmark against it?‚Äù

Lovable is a chat‚Äëbased full‚Äëstack app builder. It supports Agent/Chat/Code/visual editing, Figma import, and integrations like GitHub/Supabase/Stripe/Clerk ‚Äî very friendly for non‚Äëtechnical users and small teams; credit‚Äëbased billing, Pro starts at $25/month.

  • Agent Mode: it can ‚Äúthink, research, and change code‚Äù on its own ‚Äî read code, debug, search docs, modify code, and test.
  • Visual Edits: click elements on the page to change copy/styles, and no credits are deducted.

The company‚Äôs growth is brisk ‚Äî recent funding and revenue news suggest the category is validated.

Side‚Äëby‚ÄëSide: open‚Äëlovable vs. Lovable

Section titled ‚ÄúSide‚Äëby‚ÄëSide: open‚Äëlovable vs. Lovable‚Äù
Dimensionopen‚Äëlovable (Open Source)Lovable (Commercial SaaS)
Core capabilityClone any website ‚Üí generate Next.js/React code, develop locallyNatural‚Äëlanguage full‚Äëstack generation, supports Agent/Chat/Visual Edits
Runtime formLocal/self‚Äëhosted, MIT license, deeply modifiableHosted cloud, WYSIWYG
DependenciesFirecrawl crawling + E2B sandboxes + your chosen LLM providerBuilt‚Äëin AI capabilities and many integrations
PricingOpen source free (you pay Firecrawl/E2B/model usage)Credit‚Äëbased, Pro from $25/month
AudienceDevs with frontend skills wanting fast clone + fast customizationTeams wanting zero‚Äëbarrier app/prototype with minimal code
Typical scenariosMigrate competitor/marketing pages; rebuild legacy stack into modern React0‚Üí1 prototypes, MVPs, internal tools, turning designs into code

(Sources: both products‚Äô websites and docs/READMEs)

Hands‚ÄëOn: 5‚ÄëMinute Local Setup for open‚Äëlovable

Section titled ‚ÄúHands‚ÄëOn: 5‚ÄëMinute Local Setup for open‚Äëlovable‚Äù
  1. Clone and install
  1. Configure environment variables (.env.local)
  1. Run

These steps and dependencies are clearly documented in the official README.

Tip: Firecrawl supports full‚Äësite crawling/screenshots/Markdown/JSON; E2B sandboxes default to a 5‚Äëminute lifetime, configurable.

Three Real Developer Scenarios

Section titled ‚ÄúThree Real Developer Scenarios‚Äù

Example 1: Competitor landing page ‚Üí same‚Äëday marketing site release

Section titled ‚ÄúExample 1: Competitor landing page ‚Üí same‚Äëday marketing site release‚Äù

Scenario: Marketing wants to A/B test a new copy/layout. Approach:

  • Use open‚Äëlovable to clone a competitor page or your old landing page skeleton into React.
  • Locally wire copy, CTAs, and tracking scripts (GA/analytics).
  • Apply your design system/components, connect the backend form/CRM. Benefit: Finish ‚Äúmigrate + customize + ship‚Äù in hours, instead of re‚Äëslicing assets and rewriting styles from scratch.

Tech note: Firecrawl extracts clean page content, reducing manual copy‚Äëpaste; Next.js structure is tidy, making CI/CD straightforward.

Example 2: Modernize an ‚Äúit works but it‚Äôs old‚Äù site

Section titled ‚ÄúExample 2: Modernize an ‚Äúit works but it‚Äôs old‚Äù site‚Äù

Scenario: The company site/docs run, but the stack is aging. Approach:

  • Clone the current site to generate modern React code.
  • Use E2B sandbox‚Äëdriven scripts for batch refactors (class naming, image optimization, extracting i18n, etc.).
  • Add Tailwind/your design system to unify visuals. Benefit: Re‚Äëskin first without breaking functionality, improve maintainability, then iteratively extract components and data layers.

Example 3: Stakeholder review with something clickable on day one

Section titled ‚ÄúExample 3: Stakeholder review with something clickable on day one‚Äù

Scenario: Lots of new business ideas; leadership wants to ‚Äúsee something.‚Äù Approach:

  • Clone a public page from a similar product as the skeleton.
  • Use models to quickly swap in industry‚Äëspecific copy and inline interaction demos.
  • Integrate third‚Äëparty auth/payments/email (and migrate to a real backend later). Benefit: You have ‚Äúsomething real‚Äù the same day. Reviews focus on product value rather than ‚Äúwe haven‚Äôt built the page yet.‚Äù (When you move toward production, switch to Cursor/local repo for continued evolution.)

If you want zero‚Äëcode 0‚Üí1, Lovable‚Äôs Agent/Visual Edits and integrations are smoother. The open‚Äësource route fits teams that need engineering‚Äëgrade control of code.

Advanced: Plug into Your Daily Toolchain

Section titled ‚ÄúAdvanced: Plug into Your Daily Toolchain‚Äù
  • GitHub Actions: on PRs, run Lighthouse/Playwright to watch performance and usability.
  • Supabase/Stripe/Clerk for MVP auth/payments/data. open‚Äëlovable outputs standard React code, so integrate as usual; Lovable provides built‚Äëin guides/templates for these services.
  • Model ‚Äúmix‚Äëand‚Äëmatch‚Äù: use Claude/GPT‚Äë5 for complex logic, Groq/Kimi K2 for speed; switch via env vars as needed.

How to Choose

Section titled ‚ÄúHow to Choose‚Äù
  • You want to control code, cut subscriptions, and reuse existing web pages ‚Üí open‚Äëlovable.
  • You want 0‚Üí1 prototypes/internal tools fast, and value hosting and collaboration ‚Üí Lovable.
  • Or use a combo: first use open‚Äëlovable to grab the ‚Äúshell‚Äù and refine locally; or validate product/flows in Lovable first, then ‚Äúexport/refactor‚Äù to self‚Äëhosted.

Industry chatter often positions Lovable as ‚Äúscaffolding + visual design/flow,‚Äù while serious projects return to local engineering for polishing. open‚Äëlovable neatly covers the ‚Äúengineering‚Äëgrade control‚Äù half.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

AI‚Äëassisted development is bifurcating: one side is hosted, WYSIWYG (Lovable); the other is open‚Äësource, controllable, engineering‚Äëfriendly (open‚Äëlovable).
There‚Äôs no absolute right answer ‚Äî your team‚Äôs cost/pace/governance needs matter most.

Which side do you lean toward? Where do you think open‚Äëlovable fits best in your business? Share your real‚Äëworld scenarios in the comments.

Tags:
  • Open Lovable
  • Lovable
  • React
  • AI

terminalcp lets Claude Code manage Terminal sessions like Playwright

Aug 13, 2025
Vibe Sparking

In one sentence: terminalcp = Playwright for the terminal.
It lets an AI agent start, operate, and read any command‚Äëline tool (LLDB/GDB, Python REPL, database shells, even other AI CLIs) like a human‚Äîand lets you and me take over the same session at any time.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

You may already use Playwright/Browser for web automation‚Äîso what about an ‚Äúautomation console‚Äù for the command line?
terminalcp abstracts ‚Äúwhat a human does in the terminal‚Äù into an MCP tool: start a process ‚Üí send keystrokes ‚Üí read output ‚Üí manage multiple sessions, and also supports socket attach so you can watch and take over the AI‚Äôs actions in real time.

Why add it to your toolchain?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy add it to your toolchain?‚Äù

1) Truly interactive control
Not just ‚Äúrun a command and exit,‚Äù but persistent sessions: single‚Äëstep in LLDB/GDB, try code in a REPL, or view the ‚Äúfull screen‚Äù in TUI apps like vim/htop.

2) Two output modes, pick as needed

  • Terminal mode (stdout): captures the rendered screen buffer, perfect for debuggers and TUIs.
  • Stream mode: captures the raw text stream (ANSI stripped by default), and supports incremental reads with since_last‚Äîmore efficient for builds/logs.

3) High‚Äëfidelity PTY
Processes run in a pseudo‚Äëterminal, preserving colors/cursor moves/special key sequences‚Äîjust like human input; plus it manages multiple processes in the background so your agent doesn‚Äôt block.

4) Socket attach: the key to human‚ÄìAI collaboration
Each process automatically exposes a Unix domain socket. You can attach to an already‚Äërunning AI session to co‚Äëview and co‚Äëoperate, jumping in to help anytime.

5) More ‚ÄúAI‚Äëfriendly‚Äù than screen/tmux

  • Structured responses (JSON) instead of a wall of text.
  • Clean output (ANSI can be stripped), easier to feed into an LLM.
  • Incremental reads and lifecycle management (exit codes, etc.) built in.

Install and quick start (works with any MCP client)

Section titled ‚ÄúInstall and quick start (works with any MCP client)‚Äù

Standard config (works for most tools)
Add the server in your MCP client:

Claude Code (CLI)

Cursor
Settings ‚Üí MCP ‚Üí Add new MCP Server
Name: terminalcp, Type: command, Command:
npx @mariozechner/terminalcp@latest.

VS Code (incl. Copilot Agent)

After installation, GitHub Copilot Agent in VS Code can use it directly.

Windsurf / other MCP clients
Follow their MCP docs with the ‚Äústandard config‚Äù above, or install globally first:

Then configure:

Requirements: Node.js ‚â• 18; any MCP‚Äëcapable client (VS Code, Cursor, Windsurf, Claude Desktop, Goose, etc.).

How does it work with Claude Code / Cursor?

Section titled ‚ÄúHow does it work with Claude Code / Cursor?‚Äù

Principle: terminalcp exposes a single MCP tool terminal, and you control sessions via JSON commands: start / stdin / stdout / stream / stop / list / term-size.

Workflow A: Let Claude control another AI CLI

Section titled ‚ÄúWorkflow A: Let Claude control another AI CLI‚Äù
  1. Start Claude/Gemini CLIs (use an absolute path; shell aliases won‚Äôt work):
  1. Send input (auto submit/Enter):
  1. Read the full screen (great for TUI/debugger UIs):
  1. Clean up the process:

Shell aliases don‚Äôt apply; for interactive CLIs prefer submit:true; remember to stop when done.

Workflow B: Tail builds/logs incrementally

Section titled ‚ÄúWorkflow B: Tail builds/logs incrementally‚Äù

ANSI is stripped by default; set strip_ansi:false if you need color codes.

Workflow C: REPL / debugging

Section titled ‚ÄúWorkflow C: REPL / debugging‚Äù

Python REPL

LLDB

Collaboration superpower: socket attach (tmux‚Äëlike, but smarter)

Section titled ‚ÄúCollaboration superpower: socket attach (tmux‚Äëlike, but smarter)‚Äù

Name the process when starting it:

From your local terminal, list and attach:

  • Operate together in your own terminal;
  • Ctrl+Q to detach without killing the session;
  • Supports multiple concurrent attachments;
  • Socket paths live under ~/.terminalcp/sessions/.

How it differs from screen/tmux (tested: better for AI)

Section titled ‚ÄúHow it differs from screen/tmux (tested: better for AI)‚Äù
  • Structured responses: JSON replies that are easy for agents to parse.
  • Reliable output capture: stdout gives the rendered screen; stream supports incremental ‚Äúsince_last‚Äù reads.
  • Less noise: ANSI control codes stripped by default so escape sequences don‚Äôt swamp your context.
  • State‚Äëaware: detects process exit and error codes.
  • No guessing timing: avoids brittle sleep‚Äëstyle ‚Äúmaybe it‚Äôs done‚Äù waits.
    You can ‚Äúsimulate‚Äù some of this with tmux/screen, but it‚Äôs tedious and fragile.

Best‚Äëpractice checklist

Section titled ‚ÄúBest‚Äëpractice checklist‚Äù
  • Use absolute paths for CLIs (e.g., Claude CLI); shell aliases don‚Äôt apply.
  • For interactive commands, use {"submit":true}‚Äîor send text and \r as two steps.
  • Use stream + since_last for long tasks to avoid re‚Äëpulling full logs.
  • Name sessions + attach via sockets for quick collaboration and fire‚Äëfighting.
  • Explicitly stop when finished; on MCP client exit, leftover processes are auto‚Äëcleaned.
  • Licensed MIT‚Äîsafe to integrate into internal toolchains.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

If you‚Äôre building AI‚Äëassisted development / internal DevTools / AIOps, terminalcp turns ‚Äúeverything in the terminal‚Äù into an orchestrable API: agent control, human‚Äìagent co‚Äëoperation, automation with visibility. Starting today, let your AI not just ‚Äúrun commands,‚Äù but actually ‚Äúuse the terminal.‚Äù

Where will you plug it in first?
Build logs, kernel debugging, on‚Äëcall incident response‚Äîor turning Claude/Gemini into controllable ‚Äúsub‚Äëagents‚Äù? What do you think?

üì¶ Appendix: copy‚Äëand‚Äëpaste quick reference

Section titled ‚Äúüì¶ Appendix: copy‚Äëand‚Äëpaste quick reference‚Äù

MCP standard config (works for most clients)

Claude Code CLI

VS Code CLI

Global install (optional)

Tags:
  • terminalcp
  • AI
  • MCP
  • Terminal
  • Tmux
  • Screen

Gemini Storybook Adds Chinese Narration; Print/Export to PDF for Instant Picture Books

Aug 9, 2025
Vibe Sparking

One-sentence version: Gemini‚Äôs Storybook just shipped new features ‚Äî native Chinese read‚Äëaloud, multiple illustration styles, and print/export to PDF from the web. Make a personalized picture book for your child in under one minute.

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

Have you had this moment? It‚Äôs bedtime and your child suddenly wants ‚ÄúSuper Dino goes to Mars‚Äù; your drawers are stuffed with kids‚Äô drawings you can‚Äôt bear to toss. Storybook turns those sparks into a 10‚Äëpage illustrated tale with voice narration in one click, and can ‚Äúweave‚Äù your child‚Äôs photos or doodles right into the scenes.

Three upgrades that matter

Section titled ‚ÄúThree upgrades that matter‚Äù

1) Native Chinese narration, ready to go

Section titled ‚Äú1) Native Chinese narration, ready to go‚Äù

Google has rolled out Read‚Äëaloud, noting supported languages will expand over time; both media reports and hands‚Äëon tests indicate Chinese is already available, so parents can listen to the story in Chinese directly. The delivery sounds natural and smooth ‚Äî perfect for bedtime.

Key point: 45+ languages covered (text and audio), available on both mobile and web.

2) ‚ÄúUnlimited styles‚Äù at your fingertips

Section titled ‚Äú2) ‚ÄúUnlimited styles‚Äù at your fingertips‚Äù

Watercolor, anime, pixel art, claymation, coloring book? Switch styles with a single line, and even upload your child‚Äôs photo or doodles as inspiration for the illustrations. You can also tweak character names and scene details anytime, then generate a new version.

Official examples: from explaining the ‚Äúsolar system‚Äù to ‚Äúmoving house,‚Äù education scenarios work great too.

3) One click to booklet ‚Äî easy to share/print

Section titled ‚Äú3) One click to booklet ‚Äî easy to share/print‚Äù

Every story generates a shareable link; on the web you can print directly. In practice, Print to PDF gives you a file you can take straight to the print shop.

How to use it in three steps

Section titled ‚ÄúHow to use it in three steps‚Äù
  1. Open Gemini and start a chat: ‚ÄúHelp me make a storybook titled ‚ÄòThe Shy Dinosaur Learns to Dance‚Äô, watercolor style, for a 5‚Äëyear‚Äëold.‚Äù
  2. Add ingredients: upload your child‚Äôs dinosaur drawing/photo; specify the hero‚Äôs name and what the little monster likes to eat.
  3. Tweak: ask for ‚Äúfunnier‚Äù or ‚Äúswitch to anime style,‚Äù generate a new version; tap Read‚Äëaloud to play.

Real‚Äëworld use cases you can try now

Section titled ‚ÄúReal‚Äëworld use cases you can try now‚Äù
  • 10 minutes before bed: turn ‚Äúa small kindergarten scuffle‚Äù into a reconciliation adventure.
  • Mini lessons: explain the ‚Äúsolar system/trash sorting/traffic safety‚Äù in a coloring‚Äëbook style.
  • Memory book: stitch travel photos and family snapshots into ‚ÄúOur Jeju Island Adventure.‚Äù

Tips (pitfall avoidance)

Section titled ‚ÄúTips (pitfall avoidance)‚Äù
  • Narration languages: the note says ‚ÄúRead‚Äëaloud is currently available in select languages‚Äù. If you don‚Äôt see the button, switch languages or wait for updates.
  • Character consistency: AI illustrations can occasionally drift (e.g., character details change). Use photos and reinforce key attributes to improve consistency.
  • Sharing permissions: Work/school accounts may not allow public sharing; a personal account is most reliable.

Why this update is worth it

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy this update is worth it‚Äù
  • Barrier lowered to ‚Äúsay it and create‚Äù: parents, teachers, and creators can quickly bring ideas to life.
  • More reliable companionship: lean on AI narration when busy; read in person when free ‚Äî switch as needed.
  • Style freedom at scale: from pixel art to claymation to your child‚Äôs own drawings ‚Äî highly personalized.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Storybook lowers the bar for ‚Äútelling a good story‚Äù to simply ‚Äúsaying a sentence.‚Äù Chinese narration works, styles are playful, and print‚Äëready PDFs are easy to take with you. You bring the ideas ‚Äî it binds them into a book of love. Which one will you make first? Tell me your first theme in the comments.

  • AI

Parents' Superpower: Gemini Story Book for Creative Family Storytelling

Aug 7, 2025
Vibe Sparking

One-Minute Overview Google Gemini‚Äôs newly launched Story Book feature transforms a single spark of inspiration into a complete 10-page illustrated e-book with audio narration. Supporting 45+ languages and custom art styles, it can even incorporate children‚Äôs doodles as source material‚Äîsaving time for parents, sparking creativity in kids, and enabling rapid prototyping for professional authors.

‚ú® What Makes Gemini Story Book Magical?

Section titled ‚Äú‚ú® What Makes Gemini Story Book Magical?‚Äù
  • 10-Page Books: One prompt generates complete text + illustrations + narration package.
  • Any Art Style: Pixel art, clay animation, comics, or even black-and-white coloring books‚Äîplus photo uploads for custom characters.
  • 45 Languages: Multi-language narration makes bedtime stories work across cultures.
  • One-Minute Creation: Cloud rendering means even smartphones can handle it.

üë™ For Parents: No More ‚ÄúRunning Out of Stories‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äúüë™ For Parents: No More ‚ÄúRunning Out of Stories‚Äù‚Äù

Scenario: Creating ‚ÄúBrave Little Dinosaur‚Äôs Sleep Quest‚Äù in 5 Minutes

10-Page Script

Section titled ‚Äú10-Page Script‚Äù
  1. In the twilight forest, little dinosaur Harbi rubs his eyes but can‚Äôt fall asleep.
  2. He meets glowing fireflies and asks them to sing a lullaby.
  3. The fireflies say: ‚ÄúFirst learn to breathe deeply.‚Äù
  4. Harbi goes ‚ÄúWhooo‚Äîbreathe‚Äî‚Äù and his heartbeat slows down.
  5. Grandma Moon sends down a warm moonbeam blanket.
  6. Baby stars dance, arranging themselves into ‚ÄúZzz‚Äù in the night sky.
  7. Grandpa Wind sways the treetops, playing a rustling lullaby.
  8. Harbi feels his eyelids grow heavy and lets out a big yawn.
  9. He snuggles into the moonbeam blanket and says goodnight to the fireflies.
  10. Final scene: Harbi sleeps with a smile as the starry sky grows peaceful.

‚û°Ô∏è How-to: Paste these 10 segments into Story Book, select ‚Äúhand-drawn watercolor‚Äù style, and within 30 seconds you have an illustrated book with narration. Kids enjoy the pictures while parents get their hands free.

üëß For Kids: Become the Director

Section titled ‚Äúüëß For Kids: Become the Director‚Äù

Scenario: Yuyu and the Little Robot Learn Programming

10-Page Script

Section titled ‚Äú10-Page Script‚Äù
  1. In the classroom, 7-year-old Yuyu receives a mini robot.
  2. The robot says: ‚ÄúGive me commands, let‚Äôs go on an adventure!‚Äù
  3. Yuyu writes move forward on her tablet.
  4. The robot crosses the rainbow building block bridge.
  5. turn left‚Äîit walks around the sleeping cat.
  6. pick flower‚Äîits arm extends to pluck a blue flower.
  7. The petals turn into a rain of numbers, screen displays ‚ÄúHello World!‚Äù
  8. Yuyu exclaims with delight: code can make the world come alive!
  9. She writes a new command: dance().
  10. The robot dances with Yuyu, shouting ‚ÄúCoding is fun!‚Äù

‚û°Ô∏è How-to: Kids paste their script into Story Book, choose ‚Äúpixel comic‚Äù style, and generate their own ‚ÄúProgramming Adventure‚Äù book that‚Äôs both educational and entertaining.

üñãÔ∏è For Story Creators: Concept to Prototype in One Minute

Section titled ‚ÄúüñãÔ∏è For Story Creators: Concept to Prototype in One Minute‚Äù

Scenario: ‚ÄúCoffee Cat‚Äôs Time Travel‚Äù Proposal

10-Page Script

Section titled ‚Äú10-Page Script‚Äù
  1. An orange cat in a coffee shop steps on an alarm clock and travels back to 1925.
  2. A vintage streetcar clangs by as it searches everywhere for coffee beans.
  3. It meets a lady in a blue apron who hands over a steam coffee machine.
  4. The steam becomes a time tunnel, and the cat tumbles into 2050.
  5. A robot barista serves it cold brew.
  6. The adorable cat presses the ‚ÄúHome‚Äù button, and time reverses.
  7. Back at the original shop, it discovers the coffee smells even better.
  8. Customers line up to try the ‚ÄúTemporal Special Blend.‚Äù
  9. The orange cat lies on the counter, tail gently swaying.
  10. Finale: The shop sign gains a new line‚Äî‚ÄúThanks to our time traveler.‚Äù

‚û°Ô∏è How-to: Author pastes script ‚Üí selects ‚Äústeampunk oil painting‚Äù style ‚Üí generates prototype booklet, then decides whether to develop the script and artwork further. From inspiration to finished product in just 60 seconds.

üèÅ Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúüèÅ Conclusion‚Äù

Story Book = One-Click Picture Book Factory.

  • Parents save time, making companionship more relaxed
  • Kids become protagonists, creativity soars
  • Authors iterate quickly, accelerating market validation

Give it a try‚Äîtoss your script into Gemini and see what delightful surprises it serves up!

The Controlled AI Engineering Behind Palantir's Stock Surge

Aug 4, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Executive Summary | When AI ‚Äúexecution speed‚Äù far exceeds human review capabilities, what becomes truly scarce is engineering quality and governance systems for high-risk industries. Palantir‚Äôs emergence as a ‚Äúdual favorite‚Äù in both capital markets and industrial implementation in 2025 isn‚Äôt about better ‚Äústorytelling,‚Äù but rather about welding data‚Äîmodel‚Äîaction‚Äîaudit‚Äîdelivery into a reusable controlled AI engineering system, scaling it across ‚Äúhard scenarios‚Äù like healthcare, aerospace, manufacturing, and defense. Meanwhile, the sustained stock strength reflects the market‚Äôs pricing of this system‚Äôs commercial penetration power and cash flow certainty.

I. Why Fundamentals ‚ÄúSupport‚Äù the Stock Price‚ÄîDual Confirmation from Two Main Threads

Section titled ‚ÄúI. Why Fundamentals ‚ÄúSupport‚Äù the Stock Price‚ÄîDual Confirmation from Two Main Threads‚Äù

1) Upward Revision of Operations and Guidance Q1 2025 results showed Palantir revenue of $884 million, up +39% year-over-year, with full-year revenue guidance raised to $3.89-3.902 billion; US segment revenue grew +55%, with US Commercial revenue surging +71% to $255 million, becoming the primary growth engine.

2) Long-term Contracts + Framework Agreements as ‚ÄúCash Flow Foundation‚Äù

  • Maven Smart System: The US military added $795 million to the existing contract ceiling on May 20, 2025, extending through May 28, 2029.
  • US Army 10-Year Enterprise Agreement (EA): 75 scattered contracts consolidated into a single enterprise software agreement covering 10 years with a $10 billion ceiling, for rapid procurement of Palantir‚Äôs data and AI software (ceiling represents maximum, not committed amount).

Summary: The combination of high-certainty large clients + high-growth commercial business provides both current performance delivery and ‚Äúdurable asset‚Äù anchoring for valuation. Even with short-term volatility due to ‚Äúexpensive valuation,‚Äù institutions and media widely view ‚Äúperformance upgrades + contract frameworks‚Äù as the main support for stock strength.

II. Why Palantir?‚Äî‚ÄúAI Engineering Four-Piece Suite‚Äù Penetrates Critical Business Loops

Section titled ‚ÄúII. Why Palantir?‚Äî‚ÄúAI Engineering Four-Piece Suite‚Äù Penetrates Critical Business Loops‚Äù
  1. Ontology | Business Semantic Layer: Digitizes enterprise real-world (objects/relationships/actions) into a semantic foundation that can be ‚Äúconsensually understood and executably written back by both humans and AI.‚Äù
  2. Foundry | Data + Governance + Applications: Built-in data lineage, fine-grained permissions, and compliance templates, with fully auditable and accountable data and actions throughout.
  3. AIP | AI Platform: Builds deployable AI workflows and agents in Workflow/Logic/Agent Studio, supporting mainstream LLMs while embedding Guardrails (rules/approvals/permissions) into processes.
  4. Apollo | Cross-Domain Continuous Delivery: Unified versioning, gradual rollout, and rollback across cloud/on-premises/air-gapped security domains; official documentation details deployment methodology for classified (including IL6) and air-gapped environments.

Key Point: Not ‚Äústronger models,‚Äù but stronger engineering: Caging AI‚Äôs ‚Äúthinking speed‚Äù within institutional constraints‚Äîfrom semantics to actions as one unit, with full-chain audit and governance from data to action.

III. Four ‚ÄúHard Industry‚Äù Implementation Examples

Section titled ‚ÄúIII. Four ‚ÄúHard Industry‚Äù Implementation Examples‚Äù

‚ë† Public Health | UK NHS Federated Data Platform (FDP) NHS officially disclosed: 7-year, up to ¬£3.3 billion investment to federate scattered systems into a clinical and operational foundation for frontline use; implementation has faced progress and governance controversies (tracked long-term by British media).

‚ë° Aerospace | Airbus Skywise Industry Platform Airbus launched Skywise in partnership with Palantir in 2017, with the platform subsequently opened to the industry and officially confirmed as ‚ÄúPowered by Foundry‚Äù; Palantir overview discloses over 100 airlines now connected.

‚ë¢ Public Governance/Supply Chain | HHS/CDC‚Äôs ‚ÄúTiberius‚Äù HHS launched Tiberius during the pandemic (operational from September 2020) for full-chain vaccine and therapeutic supply allocation and tracking, with literature clearly stating it‚Äôs built on Palantir Foundry.

‚ë£ Defense & Security | Maven + Army Enterprise Agreement Maven contract expansion and the Army 10-year EA signal a shift ‚Äúfrom projects to unified software procurement systems‚Äù: treating AI/data platforms as long-term software infrastructure for operations and iteration.

IV. ‚ÄúNear Light-Speed‚Äù Quality and Risk Control: Bringing Manufacturing/Healthcare/Aerospace QA into AI

Section titled ‚ÄúIV. ‚ÄúNear Light-Speed‚Äù Quality and Risk Control: Bringing Manufacturing/Healthcare/Aerospace QA into AI‚Äù
  • Fine-grained Permissions √ó Full Lineage: Foundry‚Äôs native column/row-level permissions and data lineage enable differentiated visibility for sensitive information; actions (Action Types) are similarly controlled and logged.
  • Controlled Agents and Workflow Guardrails: AIP embeds rules, approvals, and state machines into workflows, keeping ‚Äúconversational and actionable‚Äù AI within auditable action spaces.
  • Cross-Domain Continuous Release: Apollo supports binary transfer and metadata synchronization in air-gapped and multi-classification environments, providing unified versioning, gradual rollout, and rollback capabilities.
  • Manufacturing Quality Management (QMOS): Palantir productized SPC/quality management methods into applications (QMOS) with unified data, processes, and improvement loops in Foundry; academic cases also show that engineering-level workshop data integration significantly improves team efficiency and quality loops.

V. What Capital Markets Understand‚Äî‚ÄúStock Price ‚âà Adoption Rate √ó Performance Delivery / Valuation Risk‚Äù

Section titled ‚ÄúV. What Capital Markets Understand‚Äî‚ÄúStock Price ‚âà Adoption Rate √ó Performance Delivery / Valuation Risk‚Äù‚Äù
  • Adoption Rate Being Quantified: The go-to-market centered on AIP Bootcamp (5 days from zero to usable) has been repeatedly mentioned by officials and media: over 1,300 completed since 2023, significantly compressing pilot-to-production timelines.
  • Performance Delivery Accelerating: Q1 revenue and full-year guidance upgrades, especially US Commercial high growth, serve as important basis for market expectation upgrades.
  • Valuation and Volatility: Despite stock prices reaching new highs, mainstream media repeatedly warns of high valuation/high volatility; investors need to closely track government framework agreement conversion pace and commercial sustainability.

VI. AI Implementation Checklist for ‚ÄúHard Industries‚Äù (Directly Actionable)

Section titled ‚ÄúVI. AI Implementation Checklist for ‚ÄúHard Industries‚Äù (Directly Actionable)‚Äù
  1. Loop Priority: Prioritize closable high-value/high-risk processes (production scheduling, quality control, clinical pathways, command chains), building permissions/audit/lineage into solutions from the start.
  2. Build Enterprise-Level Ontology: Unify object‚Äîrelationship‚Äîaction modeling to give AI rules to follow while keeping humans able to trace and rollback.
  3. Embed Guardrails in Workflows: Use approval, state transition, and dual-key mechanisms to limit agent action spaces; default to ‚Äúhuman-enabled, AI-controlled‚Äù.
  4. Cross-Domain Continuous Delivery: Unified versioning and gradual rollout across cloud/on-premises/air-gapped to avoid ‚Äúshadow systems‚Äù.
  5. Bootcamp-Style Progress: Create deployable minimum loops in one week, using factual evidence to drive organizational and budget support.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

When AI execution speed approaches ‚Äúlight speed,‚Äù winners aren‚Äôt the companies that talk fastest, but those that tame speed into quality and governance. Palantir has used Ontology + Foundry + AIP + Apollo to prove an executable, auditable, and reusable AI engineering system in the most challenging scenarios of healthcare, aerospace, manufacturing, and defense; sustained stock strength represents the market‚Äôs collective vote on this system‚Äôs ‚Äúsustainable delivery‚Äù capability.

Tags:
  • Finance
  • Palantir
  • NYSE: PLTR
  • AI
  • US Stock Market

Figma IPO Surges 250% on Debut: AI Design Unicorn Buy Zone at $90-110

Aug 1, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Executive Summary

Section titled ‚ÄúExecutive Summary‚Äù

Figma officially went public on the New York Stock Exchange on July 31, 2025 (NYSE: FIG), marking the largest tech IPO of 2025. The company priced 36 million shares at $33, but debut performance exceeded expectations: opening at $85 (+157%), hitting an intraday high of $125, and closing at $115.50 for a first-day gain of 250%, reaching a market cap of $56.3 billion.

Through in-depth comparative analysis with Snowflake‚Äôs (SNOW) 2020 IPO, we find that Figma achieved superior performance despite a more challenging macro environment, demonstrating its unique market position and investment value.

Investment Recommendation: Exercise caution in the near term due to lock-up expiration pressure, but maintain a bullish long-term outlook on AI-era design collaboration platform revaluation. Recommend dollar-cost averaging in the $90-110 range after lock-up adjustment period, targeting $70-80 billion market cap.

I. Figma IPO Debut Performance Analysis

Section titled ‚ÄúI. Figma IPO Debut Performance Analysis‚Äù

1.1 Complete First-Day Trading Data

Section titled ‚Äú1.1 Complete First-Day Trading Data‚Äù

Figma‚Äôs IPO debut exceeded market expectations:

  • IPO Pricing: $33 (raised from initial $25-28 range to final $30-32 range)
  • Opening Performance: $85, representing a 157% premium over IPO price
  • Intraday Range: High of $125 (+279%), low of $75 (+127%)
  • Closing Price: $115.50, first-day gain of 250%
  • Trading Volume: Over 20 million shares, turnover rate ~56%
  • Closing Market Cap: $56.3 billion

1.2 Investor Sentiment and Market Response

Section titled ‚Äú1.2 Investor Sentiment and Market Response‚Äù

Unprecedented Subscription Demand:

  • Over-subscription ratio exceeded 40x, demonstrating strong institutional investor appetite
  • Utilized bookbuilt IPO model requiring specific price submissions rather than market orders
  • First-day surge reflects market‚Äôs revaluation of design collaboration platforms in the AI era

Deviation from Expectations:

  • Market originally expected modest gains (20-50%), actual performance far exceeded forecasts
  • Primary drivers of high gains: AI integration capabilities, market dominance, improved profitability

II. Market Environment Comparison: 2025 vs 2020

Section titled ‚ÄúII. Market Environment Comparison: 2025 vs 2020‚Äù

2.1 Macroeconomic Environment Differences

Section titled ‚Äú2.1 Macroeconomic Environment Differences‚Äù

Federal Interest Rate4.25-4.5% (high-rate environment)0-0.25% (zero interest rate policy)
Inflation LevelPersistent inflation concernsStimulus-driven economic recovery
Market LiquidityCautious investment in tightening cycleExtremely accommodative monetary environment
Tech Stock SentimentAI-driven structural recoveryPandemic-benefited broad rally

2.2 IPO Market Environment

Section titled ‚Äú2.2 IPO Market Environment‚Äù

2025 IPO Market Characteristics:

  • IPO market recovering but remains relatively cautious
  • Investors increasingly focused on profitability and cash flow
  • AI-related companies commanding valuation premiums
  • High-quality SaaS companies regaining favor

2020 IPO Golden Period:

  • Global IPO fundraising near historical highs
  • Federal Reserve ‚Äúunlimited‚Äù quantitative easing
  • Tech stocks enjoying pandemic dividends
  • Extremely optimistic market sentiment

3.2 Customer Structure and Quality

Section titled ‚Äú3.2 Customer Structure and Quality‚Äù

Figma Customer Characteristics:

  • Enterprise Customers: 450K registered enterprises, 1,031 customers paying $100K+ annually (+47% YoY)
  • User Composition: 13M monthly actives, 67% non-designer users
  • International Presence: 53% of revenue from overseas markets
  • Flagship Clients: Netflix, Stripe, Duolingo, and other renowned enterprises

Snowflake Customer Comparison:

  • Enterprise Customers: 3,117 customers (at IPO), 146 Fortune 500 companies
  • Large Customer Growth: Rapid growth in $1M+ annual revenue customers
  • Geographic Distribution: Primarily concentrated in US market
  • Customer Retention: NDR of 158%

3.3 Technology Moat Analysis

Section titled ‚Äú3.3 Technology Moat Analysis‚Äù

Figma Technology Advantages:

  • Cloud-Native: No local installation required, browser-based access
  • Real-Time Collaboration: Multi-user simultaneous editing with automatic version sync
  • Deep AI Integration: 150+ AI feature mentions, significantly enhancing design efficiency
  • Ecosystem: Complete design-to-development workflow

Snowflake Technology Moat:

  • Compute-Storage Separation: Unique architectural design
  • Multi-Cloud Support: Cross-deployment on AWS, Azure, GCP
  • Elastic Computing: On-demand scaling capabilities
  • Data Sharing: Secure cross-organizational data sharing

  • Subscription Model: Highly predictable recurring revenue
  • Gross Margin Advantage: 91% gross margin far exceeds SaaS industry average
  • Customer Stickiness: 132% net dollar retention rate
  • Operating Leverage: Scale effects beginning to manifest

Snowflake Revenue Characteristics:

  • Consumption-Based Pricing: Flexible usage-based pricing model
  • High-Speed Growth: 174% growth rate facing expanding base pressure
  • Investment-Intensive: Sales expense ratio of 44%
  • R&D Investment: R&D expenses represent 38-45% of revenue

  • Operating cash flow margin of 28%
  • Q1 2025 achieved net profit of $45M
  • Continuous improvement in free cash flow
  • Profitability expected to further improve post-AI investment period

Snowflake Cash Flow Comparison:

  • Consistently positive operating cash flow
  • Free cash flow of $810M (FY2024)
  • Continued net losses but narrowing trend
  • Typical high-growth, high-investment model

V. Capital Market Performance and Stock Price Trajectory Prediction

Section titled ‚ÄúV. Capital Market Performance and Stock Price Trajectory Prediction‚Äù

5.1 Snowflake Post-IPO Stock Price Analysis

Section titled ‚Äú5.1 Snowflake Post-IPO Stock Price Analysis‚Äù

Snowflake Historical Stock Performance:

  • IPO Day: $120‚Üí$253.93 (+111.6%)
  • All-Time High: $401.89 in November 2021 (13 months post-IPO)
  • Current Level: ~$220 (July 2025)
  • Key Milestone: Buffett liquidated position in Q2 2024, stock briefly returned to IPO price

5.2 Lock-Up Period Impact Analysis

Section titled ‚Äú5.2 Lock-Up Period Impact Analysis‚Äù

Projected Lock-Up Timeline:

  • 6 months post-IPO: Employee equity begins unlocking
  • 12 months post-IPO: Major institutional investors unlock
  • 18 months post-IPO: Founder equity fully unlocked

Lock-Up Pressure Assessment:

  • Founder Dylan Field holds over 75% voting control, relatively low selling motivation
  • Institutional investors may face exit pressure
  • Employee option unlocks may bring short-term volatility

5.3 Figma 6-12 Month Price Trajectory Forecast

Section titled ‚Äú5.3 Figma 6-12 Month Price Trajectory Forecast‚Äù

Base Case Scenario (60% probability):

  • Target Price: $150-180
  • Driving Factors: Successful AI feature commercialization, increased customer willingness to pay
  • Risk Factors: Lock-up pressure, macro environment changes

Bull Case Scenario (25% probability):

  • Target Price: $200-250
  • Catalysts: AI-era design tool revaluation, renewed Adobe acquisition rumors
  • Market Cap Target: $70-80 billion

Bear Case Scenario (15% probability):

  • Target Price: $80-120
  • Risk Triggers: Intensified competition, economic recession, AI displacement threats

VI. Risk Assessment and Investment Recommendations

Section titled ‚ÄúVI. Risk Assessment and Investment Recommendations‚Äù

6.1 Primary Risk Factors

Section titled ‚Äú6.1 Primary Risk Factors‚Äù

Competitive Risks:

  • Counterattack from traditional software giants like Adobe
  • Challenges from emerging AI design tools
  • Proliferation of open-source alternatives

Technology Risks:

  • AI development potentially disrupting traditional design workflows
  • Cloud collaboration advantages being matched
  • Technology upgrade cycle risks

Market Risks:

  • Persistent high interest rate environment
  • Overall tech stock valuation correction
  • Macroeconomic recession impact

6.2 Investment Strategy Recommendations

Section titled ‚Äú6.2 Investment Strategy Recommendations‚Äù

Short-Term Strategy (0-6 months):

  • Recommend Waiting: Observe lock-up period volatility before positioning
  • Key Price Levels: $90-110 range presents good entry opportunity
  • Position Control: Initial position not exceeding 3-5%

Medium-Term Strategy (6-18 months):

  • Gradual Accumulation: Increase allocation after AI feature commercialization validation
  • Target Position: 5-8% weighting
  • Stop-Loss Setting: Consider reducing position if falls below $75

Long-Term Strategy (18+ months):

  • Core Holding: Scarce asset in AI-era design collaboration platforms
  • Valuation Target: $70-80 billion market cap reasonable
  • Holding Thesis: Dual dividend of digital transformation + AI proliferation

VII. Conclusion and Outlook

Section titled ‚ÄúVII. Conclusion and Outlook‚Äù

Figma‚Äôs successful IPO validates its unique value in AI-era design collaboration. Compared to Snowflake, Figma achieved higher first-day gains in a more challenging macro environment, demonstrating:

  1. Superior Financial Fundamentals: 91% gross margin and achieved profitability
  2. Stronger Technology Moat: Dual advantages of cloud collaboration + AI integration
  3. Broader Market Opportunity: Era opportunity of design democratization and AI tool proliferation

Investment Recommendation: Exercise near-term caution, maintain long-term bullish outlook. Recommend dollar-cost averaging in the $90-110 range after lock-up adjustment period, medium-term target price $160-200, with long-term confidence in its evolution into a platform company in AI-era design collaboration, reasonable valuation $70-80 billion.

Note: This report is based on public information analysis and does not constitute investment advice. Investing involves risks, please invest cautiously.

Competing with n8n, Dify, Coze? Google Opal Generates AI Workflows with One Sentence

Aug 1, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Google strikes again! Opal brings the magical ‚Äúwrite one sentence ‚Üí drag blocks‚Äù operation to AI workflows, creating functional mini-apps without spending a dime. Less than a week after launch, it‚Äôs already sparking heated discussions that n8n/Zapier might lose sleep over: describe your needs ‚Üí AI automatically chains together Gemini models, search, and external tools, then gives you a visual flowchart that you can drag and adjust anytime, plus one-click sharing with colleagues.

What Exactly is Opal?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat Exactly is Opal?‚Äù
  • Google Labs‚Äô brand-new experimental product, featuring a dual mode of ‚Äúnatural language + visualization,‚Äù currently 100% free and limited to US account beta testing.
  • Positioned as an AI mini-app builder: automatically arranges input boxes, prompts, Gemini model calls, tool APIs, and other steps into workflow nodes.

You describe: ‚ÄúTurn meeting notes into action items.‚Äù Opal instantly generates four nodes: ‚ÄúUpload notes ‚Üí Gemini summary ‚Üí Generate todos ‚Üí Output email,‚Äù making the workflow crystal clear.

Five Major Highlights

Section titled ‚ÄúFive Major Highlights‚Äù

1. Pure Conversational Workflow Generation

Section titled ‚Äú1. Pure Conversational Workflow Generation‚Äù

Natural language alone can connect multiple models and tools, eliminating the need for code and YAML.

2. Drag-and-Drop Visual Editing

Section titled ‚Äú2. Drag-and-Drop Visual Editing‚Äù

Want to insert new steps or modify prompts? Simply drag blocks or type another instruction.

3. Templates & Remix

Section titled ‚Äú3. Templates & Remix‚Äù

Official Starter Gallery comes built-in, with templates for blog writers, thumbnail generators, data scrapers, and more‚Äîready to grab and modify.

4. One-Click Publish & Share

Section titled ‚Äú4. One-Click Publish & Share‚Äù

After generating a link, colleagues can experience it using their own Google accounts, facilitating collaborative testing.

5. Completely Free + No Deployment Required

Section titled ‚Äú5. Completely Free + No Deployment Required‚Äù

Currently runs on Google‚Äôs backend, no need to maintain your own servers, perfect for idea validation and internal team demos.

Use Case Examples

Section titled ‚ÄúUse Case Examples‚Äù
ScenarioOne-Sentence DescriptionOpal Auto-Generated Nodes
Content Creation‚ÄùWrite an 800-word SEO-friendly blog post‚ÄùKeywords‚ÜíGemini Writing‚ÜíSEO Review‚ÜíPublish
Sales Follow-up‚ÄùSync new CRM leads to Slack and draft follow-up emails‚ÄùWebhook‚ÜíGemini‚ÜíSlack API‚ÜíGmail Draft
Product Operations‚ÄùAnalyze user feedback and generate weekly reports‚ÄùCSV Upload‚ÜíGemini Sentiment Analysis‚ÜíCharts‚ÜíGoogle Docs

Average of 10 minutes to get a minimum viable version running.

How is it Different from n8n/Zapier?

Section titled ‚ÄúHow is it Different from n8n/Zapier?‚Äù
DimensionOpaln8n
Learning CurvePure natural language, designed for non-technical usersRequires understanding node parameters, possibly writing JS
AI ModelsNative Gemini integration, visual promptsVia third-party plugins or custom configuration
PricingCurrently free, cloud-hostedCommunity edition free, commercial use requires self-hosting or paid plans
LimitationsUS Beta only, no custom code support yetHigh flexibility but steep learning curve

Three-Step Getting Started Guide

Section titled ‚ÄúThree-Step Getting Started Guide‚Äù
  1. Join Google Labs Waitlist: Log into labs.google.com ‚Üí Apply for Opal beta access.
  2. Describe: Enter your requirements in the chat box, press Enter.
  3. Refine & Share: Drag and adjust in the visual workflow ‚Üí Click Share to generate a link.

Potential Pitfalls & Opportunities

Section titled ‚ÄúPotential Pitfalls & Opportunities‚Äù
  • Geographic Restrictions: Currently only supports US accounts, domestic users need alternative access methods.
  • Extensibility: Custom functions not yet available, complex business needs may be limited.
  • Opportunities: Workflow template marketplaces, prompt component libraries, team collaboration versions could become the next wave of opportunities.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Opal downgrades ‚ÄúAI application development‚Äù from writing code to writing one sentence + dragging blocks. Any automation idea you can think of can basically be up and running before your lunch break ends. What will you build with it first? Feel free to share in the comments.

Tags:
  • AI
  • Google Opal
  • n8n
  • Dify
  • Coze

Decoding Global ChatGPT Plus Pricing: Nigeria Gives You the Best Deal?

Jul 26, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Want to subscribe to ChatGPT Plus but unsure about price differences across countries? This time, we focus on the Apple iOS platform, collecting subscription fees from multiple countries and regions for 2024-2025 and converting them to Chinese Yuan.

Let‚Äôs see which regions have the lowest subscription costs and which ones make your wallet hurt?

How Big Are the Price Differences Across Regions?

Section titled ‚ÄúHow Big Are the Price Differences Across Regions?‚Äù

ChatGPT Plus Subscription Prices by Country (Sorted by CNY Equivalent from Low to High)

Note: Prices are for monthly subscription fees in Apple iPhone app for 2024-2025.

CountryLocal Currency PriceCNY Equivalent

South Korea‚Ç©29,000 KRW150.25
Mexico$399.00 MXN154.29
UAEAED 79.99156.11
PeruS/ 79.90 PEN161.99
Albania$22.99 USD164.80
Ghana$22.99 USD164.80
India‚Çπ1,999 INR165.66
New Zealand$39.99 NZD172.54
United Kingdom¬£19.99 GBP192.49
Croatia‚Ç¨22.99 EUR192.93
Estonia‚Ç¨22.99 EUR192.93
France‚Ç¨22.99 EUR192.93
Germany‚Ç¨22.99 EUR192.93
Ireland‚Ç¨22.99 EUR192.93
Lithuania‚Ç¨22.99 EUR192.93
Slovenia‚Ç¨22.99 EUR192.93
Poland99.99 PLN198.15

Lowest Price If you‚Äôre in Nigeria, the monthly fee is about 46.51 CNY, the lowest globally, mainly due to favorable exchange rates. Pakistan comes second at about 123.87 CNY per month.

Similar Pricing Most countries cluster around 140 CNY for subscription fees. For example, Argentina, Azerbaijan, Costa Rica and others all charge $19.99 USD, equivalent to about 143 CNY at current exchange rates.

Highest Price Eurozone countries charge significantly more. Croatia, France, Germany, Ireland and others charge ‚Ç¨22.99 monthly, equivalent to 192.93 CNY. The UK isn‚Äôt cheap either at ¬£19.99, equivalent to 192.49 CNY.

How Do Exchange Rates Affect Pricing?

Section titled ‚ÄúHow Do Exchange Rates Affect Pricing?‚Äù

You can see that price differences are closely tied to exchange rates:

  • USD-priced countries: Most non-Euro countries price directly in USD, with $19.99 monthly fees around 143 CNY.
  • Local currency countries: India charges ‚Çπ1,999 monthly, equivalent to 165.66 CNY; Brazil‚Äôs R$99.90 equals 128.69 CNY.
  • Strong currency countries: Euro and Pound appreciation drives up local subscription costs.

In other words, when exchange rates change, subscription costs fluctuate accordingly. If you frequently travel or have multiple Apple IDs from different countries, it‚Äôs worth comparing prices across regions before deciding where to subscribe.

With So Many Countries, Which One Suits You?

Section titled ‚ÄúWith So Many Countries, Which One Suits You?‚Äù

Brief analysis of several common regions:

  • Asia: Nigeria and Pakistan offer relatively low prices, while Southeast Asian and Middle Eastern regions mostly use USD pricing with relatively stable costs.
  • Americas: Many Latin American countries also use USD pricing or local currencies pegged to USD, with fairly consistent fees.
  • Europe: Eurozone and UK prices are higher, so bargain hunters should think twice.

If you‚Äôre able to register Apple IDs in multiple regions, consider choosing low-price zones for subscription. However, pay attention to the legality of account and payment method issues.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

The data shows us that ChatGPT Plus subscription fees vary significantly globally. If you‚Äôre cost-conscious, choosing regional subscriptions could be a good strategy.

What‚Äôs the monthly fee in your region? What other subscription tips are worth sharing?

  • AI
  • ChatGPT
  • OpenAI
  • iOS
  • Apple

Auto Code Review and Commit Messages with GitHub Copilot in VSCode

Jul 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

üëÄ Introduction: More Code, More Problems

Section titled ‚ÄúüëÄ Introduction: More Code, More Problems‚Äù

Anyone who‚Äôs done testing, maintenance, or refactoring knows that as code grows:

  • One change affects everything
  • A small error can become a hidden bomb
  • Every commit needs a message, and writing poor ones gets you flagged in reviews

Is there a tool that can automatically check and automatically summarize?

Yes!

That‚Äôs what we‚Äôre introducing today‚ÄîGitHub Copilot‚Äôs Code Review feature + Commit Message generation.

üöÄ Quick Start: Install GitHub Copilot Extension

Section titled ‚ÄúüöÄ Quick Start: Install GitHub Copilot Extension‚Äù

In VSCode, Cursor, Kiro, Trae, Windsurf, and other extension marketplaces, search for:

GitHub Copilot

Click install, remember to log in with your GitHub account and subscribe (currently requires Copilot subscription).

After installation, a Copilot icon will appear in the sidebar‚Äîclick to open.

üí∞ GitHub Copilot Latest Pricing Overview

Section titled ‚Äúüí∞ GitHub Copilot Latest Pricing Overview‚Äù

GitHub Copilot offers three individual versions: ‚Ä¢ Free: 2,000 code completions + 50 Chat/edit requests per month, suitable for beginners to try. ‚Ä¢ Pro: $10/month (or $100/year), supports unlimited completions and chat usage, includes 300 ‚Äúadvanced model requests‚Äù (excess charged at $0.04/request). ‚Ä¢ Pro+: $39/month (or $390/year), upgrades Pro to 1,500 advanced requests, supports more AI models and priority access.

Additionally, Copilot Business (team/enterprise version) costs $19/month per user, including team management, security policies, and 300 advanced request quota.

üîç One-Click AI Code Review

Section titled ‚Äúüîç One-Click AI Code Review‚Äù

Where‚Äôs the Entry Point?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs the Entry Point?‚Äù

In VSCode‚Äôs Source Control panel (‚åò+Shift+G), you can see the change list.

Click the button in the red box as shown:

üí¨ Icon = Code Review - Uncommitted Changes

Copilot will automatically analyze your changes, providing suggestions file by file, line by line.

What Does Copilot Say?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhat Does Copilot Say?‚Äù

Let‚Äôs look at a real screenshot (belowüëá):

Copilot automatically analyzes and says:

User.new expects individual parameters (username, password), but you passed a hash. Consider using the splat operator.

And provides modification suggestions:

Isn‚Äôt this more efficient than finding errors one by one?

‚úçÔ∏è One-Click Commit Message Generation

Section titled ‚Äú‚úçÔ∏è One-Click Commit Message Generation‚Äù

Every time you commit, do you want to lazily write ‚Äúfix bug‚Äù or ‚Äúupdate‚Äù? üôÉ

GitHub Copilot helps you automatically generate semantic messages:

Just click this buttonüëá:

It will generate an appropriate commit description based on your changes, such as:

feat: Refactor specs to utilize FixturesSetting for user and patient data across multiple test files

Accurate, clear, and follows semantic commit standards.

‚úÖ Summary of Benefits You Get:

Section titled ‚Äú‚úÖ Summary of Benefits You Get:‚Äù
  • Automated Code Review: Quickly identify logic errors and unreasonable code patterns
  • Automatic Commit Message Generation: Never worry about ‚Äúcan‚Äôt think of a name‚Äù for changes
  • Multi-file Multi-paragraph Support: Handle entire modifications seamlessly

üß† A Question:

Section titled ‚Äúüß† A Question:‚Äù

How do you usually do code reviews? Would you be willing to let AI help you review and write commits?

Feel free to share your experience in the comments~

Tags:
  • AI
  • GitHub Copilot
  • VS Code
  • Code Review
