Round-tripping PDFs with Claude Code

Jul 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

Introduction

Section titled ‚ÄúIntroduction‚Äù

In daily work, contracts, agreements, BLE communication specifications‚Ä¶ companies are never short of PDFs. They look beautiful but are a nightmare to edit: copy-paste gets messy, formatting goes haywire. This article shares a practical ‚Äúreverse PDF ‚Üí Markdown ‚Üí PDF‚Äù workflow using Claude Code in three steps, while maintaining an editable Word version.

Why Go Through This Trouble?

Section titled ‚ÄúWhy Go Through This Trouble?‚Äù
  • Only PDF left, Word lost ‚Üí Cannot maintain
  • Partners only accept PDFs ‚Üí Format must be unified
  • Want to add new APIs/tables ‚Üí Need text-editable format

Claude Code perfectly fills this gap.

Overall Workflow

Section titled ‚ÄúOverall Workflow‚Äù

PDF ‚Üí Markdown (Editable) ‚Üí Update ‚Üí PDF/Word The core is leveraging Claude Code‚Äôs multimodal parsing and formatting capabilities.

‚ë† PDF ‚ûú Markdown

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë† PDF ‚ûú Markdown‚Äù

Goal: Preserve titles, tables, image references, convert to clean .md in one click.

Recommended Prompt

Claude Code will automatically recognize the PDF structure and generate a clear Markdown document.

‚ë° Edit & Update Markdown

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë° Edit & Update Markdown‚Äù

Goal: Add latest APIs, correct descriptions, make documentation live again.

Automatic Code Analysis

Claude Code will automatically analyze code blocks in Markdown, find potential issues, and suggest improvements.

Or manually add details

‚ë¢ Markdown ‚ûú PDF

Section titled ‚Äú‚ë¢ Markdown ‚ûú PDF‚Äù

Goal: Output updated documentation as standard PDF for partner submission.

Recommended Prompt

Claude Code will generate a uniformly formatted PDF document.

Bonus: Generate Saveable Word Version

Section titled ‚ÄúBonus: Generate Saveable Word Version‚Äù

Need a Word version for the company? Use single-page HTML as a workaround!

Markdown ‚ûú Single-file HTML

Claude Code will generate an HTML file containing all styles.

Then:

  1. Word opens HTML ‚Üí Save as DOCX/PDF
  2. Get locally editable Word + final PDF, two birds with one stone.

Conclusion

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion‚Äù

Through Claude Code, bring out-of-control PDFs back to the editable world, then painlessly output standard PDF/Word, solving both ‚Äúformat unity‚Äù and ‚Äúcontent maintainability‚Äù pain points.

What other stubborn PDFs do you have that need reviving? Leave a comment and chat‚Äîmaybe the next article will cover your scenario!

Tags:
  • AI
  • Claude Code
  • PDF
  • Markdown
  • Word
  • HTML
  • Documentation

Isolated Spec Fixtures in Rails with Kiro: Clean, Consistent, Configurable

Jul 25, 2025
Vibe Sparking

‚ÄúWhy does it pass locally but always fails in CI?‚Äù

‚ÄúThe same API returns different data in SIT and TEST environments?‚Äù

In real projects, if you‚Äôve encountered test data chaos and testing instability due to environment inconsistencies, this article will definitely help you.

Our team recently combined Kiro tools to automatically generate and implement a simple yet practical solution in Rails projects: Spec test data managed with environment isolation. This not only makes testing more reliable but also opens new possibilities for multi-environment collaboration.

üß† Why Environment-Isolated Test Data?

Section titled ‚Äúüß† Why Environment-Isolated Test Data?‚Äù

In real scenarios, we often have multiple deployment environments: dev, sit, test, production‚Ä¶

Each environment may use different accounts, device IDs, patient data, and other fixtures. Without proper management, test scripts easily couple to specific data, leading to:

  • Test data pollution across multiple environments
  • Local tests pass, CI fails
  • ‚ÄúGhost bugs‚Äù: hard to reproduce, hard to troubleshoot

So we want to achieve one thing:

Test data should be loadable by environment and injectable on demand, just like configuration files

‚úÖ How Did Kiro Help Us Complete This Process?

Section titled ‚Äú‚úÖ How Did Kiro Help Us Complete This Process?‚Äù

First, we described the problem clearly using a documentation-oriented approach:

Then we looked at Kiro‚Äôs proposed solution:

Kiro‚Äôs solution not only makes testing ‚Äúclean and tidy‚Äù but also solves common environment data conflicts in team collaboration.

It accomplished the following:

  • Built the fixtures_setting.yml file structure and extracted commonly used data from multiple environments
  • Wrote a universal FixturesSetting utility class
  • Helped review all data usage patterns in spec/requests
  • Implemented environment-specific test execution with TARGET_ENV=sit rspec

Finally, Kiro achieved:

One set of specs, runs across all environments

Not only stable but also convenient for CI/CD continuous integration, and can serve as a ‚Äútest data management center‚Äù for other services to read.

üîß How to Do It? Easy Setup with Kiro + YML

Section titled ‚Äúüîß How to Do It? Easy Setup with Kiro + YML‚Äù

Kiro adopted a three-step solution, centered around one configuration file + one loader class + spec calling conventions:

üìÅ Step 1: Create Unified Fixture Configuration File

Section titled ‚ÄúüìÅ Step 1: Create Unified Fixture Configuration File‚Äù

Kiro added a file:

Inside, fixture data is managed by environment name classification, extracting commonly used users, patients, and other data from spec/requests.

This way, our test data is no longer scattered across individual spec files but centrally managed and organized by environment.

üíé Step 2: Use Ruby Class to Read Configuration Data

Section titled ‚Äúüíé Step 2: Use Ruby Class to Read Configuration Data‚Äù

Kiro implemented a small utility class FixturesSetting specifically for loading this yml file:

This way, anywhere in the code, you can get the corresponding environment‚Äôs test data through FixturesSetting[ENV['TARGET_ENV']], very flexible.

üß™ Step 3: Use Environment Data in Specs

Section titled ‚Äúüß™ Step 3: Use Environment Data in Specs‚Äù

Let‚Äôs look at a specific example. We have a user login API test:

Then when running tests, we just need to set the environment variable:

You can easily switch to test, uat, prod, each environment has its own fixtures, mutually non-interfering.

üß© Extended Thinking: How Else to Optimize?

Section titled ‚Äúüß© Extended Thinking: How Else to Optimize?‚Äù
  • Can be combined with dotenv or Rails credentials to auto-inject environment variables
  • Consider wrapping FixturesSetting as a gem or engine for better reuse
  • Later could also support dynamically generated data instead of hardcoded values

üí¨ What Do You Think?

Section titled ‚Äúüí¨ What Do You Think?‚Äù

Have your teams encountered test data chaos issues when doing API testing? Do you think this solution is suitable for your projects?

Feel free to leave comments for discussion‚Äîwe can polish more universal testing management tools together~

üìå Summary

Section titled ‚Äúüìå Summary‚Äù

In this article, we introduced how to combine Kiro‚Äôs proposed solution in Rails projects:

  • Use YAML to manage test data for different environments
  • Use utility classes to read and inject into specs
  • Achieved environment-specific execution, data isolation, and controllable testing

This is a simple, practical, and scalable test environment isolation solution. Making tests cleaner and collaboration more confident.

Tags:
  • AI
  • Rails
  • Rspec
  • Testing
  • Vibe Coding Practices

AI Era: Software Engineers' Core Competency is Managing Software Projects

Jul 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

üí•Introduction: When ‚ÄúTech Gurus‚Äù Are No Longer Popular

Section titled ‚Äúüí•Introduction: When ‚ÄúTech Gurus‚Äù Are No Longer Popular‚Äù

Remember that era? As long as you could write code, handle system architecture, dominate LeetCode, and shine with technical prowess, you could walk tall. But AI came, and everything changed.

Today, someone who barely codes can piece together an App with ChatGPT; a newcomer can write automation scripts with Claude, even running tests on the side.

At this point, you might wonder: ‚ÄúWhat value do we engineers actually have?‚Äù

Actually, the answer is clear:

In the AI era, truly valuable skills aren‚Äôt technical details, but management capabilities.

Not traditional ‚Äúteam leading,‚Äù but broad engineering management capabilities‚Äî how to define objectives, organize information, decompose tasks, coordinate AI and humans, evaluate outcomes, and adjust timely.

üß†Part One: In the Allocation Economy Era, Everyone is a ‚ÄúManager‚Äù

Section titled ‚Äúüß†Part One: In the Allocation Economy Era, Everyone is a ‚ÄúManager‚Äù‚Äù

Dan Shipper proposed a very interesting concept:

We‚Äôre transitioning from the ‚Äúknowledge economy‚Äù to the ‚Äúallocation economy‚Äù era.

Previously, competition was about who mastered more skills; Now, it‚Äôs about who can better allocate AI, information, and resources.

This isn‚Äôt empty talk, but your real daily experience working with AI:

  • How do you clearly explain tasks so AI understands you?
  • How do you break complex requirements into pieces for different tools to handle efficiently?
  • How do you select models, set prompts, and evaluate result quality?
  • When do you let AI run autonomously, and when should you intervene with details?

Sound familiar? Isn‚Äôt this exactly a ‚Äúmanager‚Äôs‚Äù daily work?

Most importantly:

AI has lowered management barriers, allowing everyone to be a project owner.

üõ† Part Two: What Are the Most Valuable Core Skills for the Future?

Section titled ‚Äúüõ† Part Two: What Are the Most Valuable Core Skills for the Future?‚Äù

Based on Dan Shipper‚Äôs observations and hands-on practice, the scarcest future skills include:

  • Information organization and problem articulation: Not about knowing more, but expressing problems clearly.
  • Resource scheduling and task decomposition: Assigning tasks to appropriate people/AI and coordinating outputs.
  • Judgment and result evaluation capabilities: Is this work good? Is it trustworthy?
  • Vision setting and goal driving: Telling AI and teams ‚Äúwhere we‚Äôre going.‚Äù

More bluntly:

You need to learn to ‚Äúrun a company‚Äù with AI, not ‚Äúwrite code‚Äù yourself.

üîÅ Part Three: Generalist Value Returns, Small Teams Are the Future

Section titled ‚ÄúüîÅ Part Three: Generalist Value Returns, Small Teams Are the Future‚Äù

Another huge change AI brings is making ‚Äúgeneralists‚Äù more valuable.

In Dan‚Äôs team of 15 people, everyone wears multiple hats:

  • One person can code, design, and handle operations;
  • A project can go from 0 to launch with just 2-3 people;
  • AI becomes ‚Äúexpert patches,‚Äù helping generalists quickly reach standards in various fields.

You no longer need a decade-deep specialist for every position. Instead, you need people with big picture thinking + hands-on ability + AI collaboration skills.

Future companies might resemble today‚Äôs startup small teams:

Everyone can lead projects, everyone can collaborate with AI for production, everyone has a ‚Äúmanagerial mindset‚Äù.

üöÄConclusion: AI Isn‚Äôt a Silver Bullet, Real Capabilities Are Trump Cards

Section titled ‚ÄúüöÄConclusion: AI Isn‚Äôt a Silver Bullet, Real Capabilities Are Trump Cards‚Äù

Yes, AI is powerful, but it‚Äôs not divine. It can‚Äôt set objectives for you or judge truly valuable directions.

Future software engineers won‚Äôt just be ‚Äúcode writers‚Äù or just architecture-savvy ‚Äútech gurus.‚Äù

They‚Äôll be:

‚ÄúEngineering managers‚Äù who can orchestrate tools, evaluate outcomes, decompose problems, and drive progress.

So instead of grinding new models and frameworks, consider:

Have you truly mastered the management skills of ‚Äúallocating AI capabilities‚Äù?

üìå What‚Äôs your take? Do you have similar transformation experiences, or are you feeling ‚ÄúAI taking jobs‚Äù anxiety? Welcome to share your understanding of future engineer capability models!

Tags:
  • AI
  • Software Engineering

Startup AI Deployment Practical Guide: From Training to Impact, Step by Step!

Jul 22, 2025
Vibe Sparking

In recent years, generative artificial intelligence (AI) has sparked a wave of enterprise transformation. Companies across industries have announced ‚ÄúAI-first‚Äù strategies, integrating AI into daily operations. As a hedge fund CEO said, not using AI is like refusing to use the internet in 1995 - these tools can instantly make people smarter and more efficient. Many leading companies have already taken action: Companies like Shopify have even made using AI a hard performance requirement, requiring employees to prove AI cannot handle a task before requesting new resources, and prioritizing AI exploration in project prototype phases. Duolingo also announced in a company-wide letter its complete transformation into an ‚ÄúAI-first‚Äù company, developing 148 new courses through AI in less than a year, exceeding the total of the past 12 years combined! Clearly, skillful AI use can bring 10x to 100x efficiency improvements. For startups, how to catch this wave and truly implement AI in team work is a key issue related to efficiency and competitiveness. This article combines industry best practices to provide startups with a practical guide for gradually implementing AI training and application deployment.

Step One: Leadership Leads by Example, Creating AI-First Culture

Section titled ‚ÄúStep One: Leadership Leads by Example, Creating AI-First Culture‚Äù

To successfully drive AI implementation, executive commitment and participation are crucial. CEOs and founding teams must lead by example, personally experiencing and daily using AI tools like ChatGPT and Claude. If leaders themselves use AI daily and find it ‚Äúcool,‚Äù the entire company often follows quickly. This isn‚Äôt exaggeration: observations show that whether CEOs actively use AI is the primary predictor of successful enterprise AI implementation. Companies with CEO-driven initiatives see more employee enthusiasm for trying AI and easier innovation culture formation.

Leadership should clearly communicate ‚ÄúAI-first‚Äù strategic commitment to all employees. For example, Shopify CEO‚Äôs internal memo stated bluntly: ‚ÄúInstinctively using AI is now a basic expectation for everyone‚Äù. This letter wasn‚Äôt generic encouragement but elevated AI application to strategic and institutional heights, requiring everyone from CEO to all employees to integrate AI into work without exception. Leaders can follow similar approaches, issuing company-wide letters or declaring AI strategy in all-hands meetings, writing ‚Äútry AI before asking for human help‚Äù into company culture guidelines and performance evaluations. Importantly, leadership must truly invest, deeply understanding AI‚Äôs potential and limitations rather than treating it merely as an IT department matter. Only when leadership has proper awareness and leads by example can they set examples for the entire company and create an organizational atmosphere embracing AI.

Step Two: Survey Current State, Identify AI Application Scenarios

Section titled ‚ÄúStep Two: Survey Current State, Identify AI Application Scenarios‚Äù

After establishing commitment, the next step is finding the most suitable entry points for introducing AI into team work. Startups can conduct internal surveys or brainstorming sessions to inventory repetitive, tedious, time-consuming tasks across positions and business processes. For example, does customer service frequently answer repetitive questions? Does the marketing team need extensive copywriting? Do developers perform repetitive code reviews? These areas could all benefit from AI efficiency improvements. Many AI consulting advisors entering enterprises interview various teams about workflow processes, identify pain points that AI can optimize, then form briefings with solution approaches for management feedback. When startup teams are small, founders or designated ‚ÄúAI leaders‚Äù can personally lead this process, mapping AI applications: listing short-term AI use cases to try and long-term projects to explore.

Based on this, establish an internal knowledge base to accumulate these survey results and potential use cases. For instance, compile collected cases and operation guides into documents, or even build a simple internal chatbot where employees can ask ‚ÄúHow do we use AI to accelerate XX tasks?‚Äù and get answers. This resembles consultation advisors‚Äô interview material retrieval bots built for clients, helping employees self-explore AI opportunities. Through such knowledge bases, team members encountering problems in daily work can conveniently search for AI solutions, gradually forming ‚Äúask AI first‚Äù habits.

Step Three: Customized Training, Comprehensively Improve Team AI Skills

Section titled ‚ÄúStep Three: Customized Training, Comprehensively Improve Team AI Skills‚Äù

After determining application scenarios, teams need systematic AI skills training. Surveys show nearly half of employees want formal AI training and consider it the best way to improve AI adoption rates. Startups can create targeted training plans based on each position‚Äôs needs. AI is general-purpose technology with vastly different applications across functions. Therefore training must align with business: let marketing personnel learn generative AI copywriting, customer service learn conversational model customer responses, product and technical teams learn AI-assisted coding and prototype design.

Practice proves small-step-quick-run training is more effective. A 4-week training sprint can be arranged: using 1 hour weekly for training or workshops over four consecutive weeks covering key skills. Each session focuses on one theme like ‚ÄúAI writing techniques,‚Äù ‚ÄúPrompt construction skills,‚Äù ‚ÄúUsing AI for data analysis,‚Äù allowing employees to gradually digest and absorb. Between training intervals, encourage learners to practice in actual work, applying learning to current tasks and sharing feedback at next training. To ensure training unifies knowledge and action, managers should design job-relevant exercises for each employee. For example, prepare simulated customer Q&A prompts for sales personnel, provide AI resume screening demonstrations for HR. Such customized scenario practice helps employees genuinely experience AI‚Äôs help with their work, improving learning interest and usage intention.

Worth noting, training should teach not just ‚Äúhow to use‚Äù but also help teams understand AI limitations and best practices, managing expectations. Current AI models aren‚Äôt omnipotent and still have errors and imperfections. If unrealistic high expectations are placed on AI, disappointment and abandonment may occur when encountering setbacks. Therefore training should introduce AI-suitable task types, common errors and countermeasures, helping employees establish correct mindset: treat AI as a powerful assistant, not a perfect magic wand. When employees master skills while maintaining rational expectations, AI tools can truly integrate long-term into their daily work.

Step Four: Discover Internal AI Pioneers, Drive Experience Sharing

Section titled ‚ÄúStep Four: Discover Internal AI Pioneers, Drive Experience Sharing‚Äù

Within teams, there often exists different acceptance levels for new technology - roughly 10% of employees are extremely enthusiastic about trying AI, 10% may resist or oppose, while the remaining 80% mainly observe - if someone guides them to use it in their work, they‚Äôre willing to try. Startups should fully leverage the power of the front 10% ‚ÄúAI geek‚Äù employees, making them internal AI pioneers and demonstrators.

Specific measures include:

  • Designate AI champions or mentors: Select ‚ÄúAI champions‚Äù from employees enthusiastic about exploring AI to serve as mentors in teams, ready to answer colleagues‚Äô questions about AI tools and share usage techniques. This gives pioneers honor and responsibility while providing nearby learning examples for others.

  • Establish sharing mechanisms: Regularly organize AI experience sharing sessions. Weekly online or offline sharing where employees showcase AI-completed work cases, problems encountered, and solution insights. Such ‚Äúweekly prompt shows‚Äù let colleagues from different positions learn from each other and spark new creative ideas.

  • Internal communication channels: Build company internal AI exchange platforms like Slack channels, WeChat groups, encouraging employees to discuss AI discoveries and applications anytime. From companies like Shopify‚Äôs experience, providing abundant AI tools and encouraging sharing success and failure cases in internal channels helps create supportive learning atmospheres. When people see colleagues using AI to solve actual problems, they‚Äôre more motivated to try themselves.

  • Experience libraries and prompt libraries: Collect and organize employee-shared excellent use cases and prompts into AI experience libraries or prompt handbooks. This way newcomers or temporarily idea-less employees can reference others‚Äô successful cases, lowering exploration barriers. Transform early users‚Äô exploration results into company-wide reusable processes and templates, avoiding detours and achieving quick results.

Through above methods, transform scattered personal exploration into company-wide collective learning. By providing platforms and rewards for AI pioneers, letting them stand out, the entire organization‚Äôs learning and innovation will automatically spread. This is one secret to advancing AI implementation: let internal innovation sparks create prairie fire.

Step Five: Establish Incentive Mechanisms, Normalize AI Applications

Section titled ‚ÄúStep Five: Establish Incentive Mechanisms, Normalize AI Applications‚Äù

To prevent AI applications from being flash-in-the-pan phenomena, they must be integrated into daily work assessment and incentive mechanisms, forming continuous improvement loops. As experts point out, relying solely on harsh notices to drive change is high-risk unless accompanied by training, tools, and management support, otherwise it easily becomes formalistic. Therefore, companies need institutional safeguards for AI implementation.

Performance evaluation and goal binding: Incorporating AI usage into employee performance indicators is directly effective. For example, examining whether employees used AI tools when completing tasks, usage frequency and incremental value created; teams needing additional staff or budget must prove they‚Äôve fully utilized AI for efficiency improvements. This mechanism sends clear signals: AI application isn‚Äôt optional but work‚Äôs new normal and basic requirement. Of course, setting indicators should be reasonable, guidance-focused, avoiding excessive pressure causing resentment. The key is making employees realize skillful AI use will positively impact personal development and team performance.

Data tracking and rankings: Following hedge fund Walleye‚Äôs approach, establish AI usage dashboards or leaderboards. For example, track each team or individual‚Äôs ChatGPT tool usage frequency, even evaluate AI-assisted task completion quantities. Regularly (weekly or monthly) publish this data, recognizing employees with significant progress or good prompt sharing in company-wide emails. This transparency creates ‚Äúfriendly competition‚Äù atmosphere on one hand, encouraging everyone to learn AI competitively; on the other hand, it lets management grasp real-time AI implementation across departments, timely discovering obstacles and highlights.

Reward early adopters: Give rewards and recognition to employees actively embracing AI with significant results. For example, material rewards, promotion considerations, or inviting them to share experiences in broader ranges. Walleye even linked AI adoption to rewards, using leaderboards and reward mechanisms to encourage fastest learners, making AI application truly ‚ÄúMandatory, not optional‚Äù internally. Startups can design localized incentives like monthly ‚ÄúAI Innovation Awards,‚Äù commending teams with significant cost savings or efficiency improvements.

Integrate results into business objectives: Include AI-related task indicators in OKRs or quarterly goals, like ‚Äúautomate X processes using AI this quarter,‚Äù ‚Äúincrease team per-capita customer request processing by Y% (with AI tools).‚Äù This drives business leaders to actively consider using AI for business improvements. When setting these goals, consider employee willingness and feedback, ensuring goals balance feasibility and challenge.

Through systems and incentives, transform employee AI use from one-time activities to long-term habits. Only when everyone realizes the company continuously cares about and rewards AI application effectiveness will AI truly integrate into organizational DNA, becoming a natural component of daily work. Once this positive cycle begins, team AI maturity will increasingly improve, with benefits gradually manifesting and amplifying.

Step Six: Deep AI Tool Integration, Optimize Business Processes

Section titled ‚ÄúStep Six: Deep AI Tool Integration, Optimize Business Processes‚Äù

After training and culture are established, the key is deeply integrating AI into company daily business processes, achieving real efficiency leaps. McKinsey research shows employees consider seamlessly integrating AI into existing workflows as an important factor promoting daily use (45% of employees hold this view). Startups should examine core processes, exploring how to redesign these processes using AI to achieve higher output with less human input.

Examples include customer service automation, meeting transcription and knowledge management, internal information search, development process integration, and data analysis for decision-making. Through these measures, startups can let existing personnel achieve multiplied effectiveness with AI without significantly increasing headcount. Once AI integrates into main business processes, many previously ‚Äúimpossible tasks‚Äù become possible.

Conclusion: Continuous Learning, Embracing the Future

Section titled ‚ÄúConclusion: Continuous Learning, Embracing the Future‚Äù

Successfully implementing AI training and applications in a startup isn‚Äôt accomplished overnight but requires continuous learning and iteration. This transformation involves technology, processes, and culture, requiring executive commitment, full participation, and patient refinement. The good news is most successful practices show AI implementation mainly brings efficiency improvements and capability expansion rather than large-scale layoffs. The AI era curtain has just opened. The earlier teams master this ‚Äúefficiency key,‚Äù the more opportunities startups have to stand out in fierce competition. Instead of watching, take action; let AI work for you, do more and better - the future is here, start now!

References:

  1. RichChat, ‚ÄúEmbrace or Eliminate? Discussing Shopify CEO‚Äôs Internal Letter Mandating Company-wide AI Learning‚Äù
  2. RichChat, ‚ÄúAI-First Transformation Wave: From Shopify to Duolingo and Box, What Do AI-First Organizations Look Like?‚Äù
  3. Stuart Willson, LinkedIn post: ‚ÄúHow Walleye Capital leveraged AI for $10B AUM‚Äù
  4. Dan Shipper podcast interview, ‚ÄúAt This $10B Hedge Fund, Using AI Just Became Mandatory‚Äù transcript
  5. McKinsey ‚ÄúAI in the workplace: A report for 2025‚Äù
  6. Lenny‚Äôs Newsletter podcast interview, ‚ÄúThe AI-native startup: ‚Ä¶ | Dan Shipper‚Äù summary
Tags:
  • AI
